reviewText:
TL;DR: Great game + great devs + great originality = great purchase. This is one of the games i dare recommend to people without attaching a caveat lector.

Three hundred seventy-three. That is, at the time of writing this review, the amount of games in my steam library. Yet despite having a fair amount of games to compare Thea too i just cannot find any combination of games that would adequate serve as a comparison. Thea manages to blend several game genres surprisingly well - you will see elements of the survival genre mixed with RPG, civilization (city-building) and roguelike-lite genre while playing the game. It also has a set of game systems that i do not recognize as being borrowed from other games in those genres. Thus, If you are looking for a refreshingly original title instead of the so-manieth title that is essentially a clone of another game you played before i can strongly recommend Thea.

Intro - What is the game about?The premise of the game is that you are a god in a post-apocalyptic world, who managed to survive with a handful of followers. Your villagers have set up a new village and now it is up to you to make that village thrive and to uncover what happened to the world. Initially you will be focused on exploring the world around you by sending out expedition parties that map the world, find old ruins that can be looted for materials and fend of enemies that threaten your town. Meanwhile random events and an overarching main quest focusing on the fate of the world will keep you busy. If you wish to do so you are free to simply ignore the games main quest and focus on your village instead if that is your preference.

One thing of note is that the game is centered around this single village. You cannot build new villages or expand as you would in civilization-type games. Neither will you be be fielding gigantic armies to take over the world - you will instead start the game with about ten villagers in your town and thats all you have. Villagers are not a particularly renewable commodity either; They can and will die if you end up having bad luck or play poorly. Every lost villager actually hurts and this is not just due to them being a somewhat hard to replace resource. Each and every single one of your villagers has his own set of equipment, a class and a set of skills. You will know that the villager you lost was responsible for crafting half of the armors your other villagers use. You will know that the warrior that died had been around since the start of the game, slowly upgrading his stick sword to a full suit of armor and decent weaponry only to fall to a horde of skeletons. You will know all of them, and you will not want to lose any of them.

Combat, Crafting and QuestsA point of interest is the games combat system, which is unlike any i played in this type of game. Combat and some of the other games activities resolve around a card game system that determines the outcome of each event. In this card system each of your villagers is represented by a card that contains their stats, skills and abilities in combat. Each turn you and your opponent play cards until all villagers and opponents are on the table, after which the actual resolution of the fight or challenge will take place. The rules of the card system are somewhat hard to describe in a review but in practice they works rather well, creating a system that is easy to learn but hard to master. There is plenty of tactical variety to the card system that allows you to develop optimal tactics and gear for your villagers, without taking overly long. An entire fight takes 1-3 minutes at most from start to finish.

Also worth mentioning is the crafting system. The game map around the village is procedurally generated and randomly seeded with resources that can be harvested. Since you only have a single village retrieving these resources requires the formation of expedition parties that go and get them for you (Always a risk, since there are plenty of dangers on the world map). Each resource has its own quality and advantages that tie into the crafting system. For example: A recipe may have the base requirement for Wood" and "Metal" to be added. If you add regular wood the result will be average
date:
but if you add dark wood the crafted weapon will be stronger and have poison damage. The same applies for metal so you can mix and match the stats you want. Factor into this that each weapon type functions differently in the combat card game and you will end up with a resource gathering system that actually matters quite a bit.

I cannot write in great detail about quests since the survival gameplay keeps distracting me time and again. So far i know that the game features both a a (long) storyline quest and random event quests. The former of these is the overarching story of the game while the latter happen at random. Each random event quest i encountered so far provides the player with a situation they must react to. If you see see slave hunter what would you do? Try and convince them to hand one over to you? Try and set up an ambush? Or just charge in yelling? Or perhaps... you just want to ignore the situation and walk away. So far i haven't encountered the same random event quest twice after about 20 hours of gametime though random quests are somewhat rare. Even so i am bound to believe the developers claim that the game contains 130k words of quests text - more than the average novel.

ConclusionNormally i like to end a review with a list of the games good and bad points but in this case i simply cannot - for the sheer reason i cannot really find any problem severe enough to warrant a specific mention. Yes
recommended: the game is early access and has a few bugs but they are being fixed exceptionally fast once reported. The developers themselves are highly active on the forum and listen and respond to criticism and suggestions which is always a plus - i think we all met companies on steam who prefer the reviled "Lock
hoursPlayed: ban and delete" approach when dealing with those matters.\n\nUsually i don't like writing reviews that only seems to sing praise without adding a critical note since a good review balances the positive and the negative aspects of a game. In this case I will be making the proverbial exception to the rule since complaining for the sake of complaining makes even less sense. If you actually managed to reach this line by reading this entire wall of text stop wasting time and buy the game. I am nigh certain you won't regret it - though you might end up regretting a lost night of sleep or two afterwards."

reviewText:
As an author primarily of dark fantasy allegory, myth, and bleak science-fiction, Thea: The Awakening speaks to my soul.  As a woman, it's nice to see some grave lady deities represented - Mokosh being my favorite.  Whoever did the art for this game deserves special recognition.

So much about this takes me back to my childhood, poring over old books and fantasy accessories for CRPGs and the old artwork in the Diablo booklets.  It has that classic, gritty 90's American pop-art style that will always be a part of my mental landscape.

As a game it functions well.  I'm a strategy addict, and a survival-game addict, so putting these two together ALONG WITH gorgeous art and serious mythological chops?  I couldn't be happier.

Well, I could.  There are issues.

- Tedious micromanagement.  I'm not a huge fan.  Some quality of life improvements would be great, chiefly, the ability to hit a single button when creating a new expedition and automatically supply it with, say, twenty or thirty days of a variety of food and fuel.  As it stands, this is the single most tedious thing in the game, having to manually drag every single item and manually enter in the numbers.  I'm old.  It hurts my poor hand after a while, and interrupts the flow of the game.

- Weird card game combat.  Am I the only one who just clicks auto-resolve every time?  Like, EVERY time?  Even if I liked the card game (I don't really care for it) it doesn't add much to the experience, in my opinion.  This isn't Age of Wonders 3, we don't have the budget for a serious hex field and some turn-based combat, I get that.  It just feels like a waste of time.  But since it doesn't force itself on you, I suppose it's not a big deal.

Those are my only two issues, really.  Some people have complained about the 'writing' being bad because the person who wrote this game's events and designed the world clearly has some incredibly MINOR issues with English.  I wouldn't even call them issues, it's more like reading an accent, which I enjoy, as it gets me looking at my native tongue in different ways.  weakened

reviewText:
I have never taken the time to write a game review before, but I feel compelled to do so for “Thea: The Awakening.”

Thea is part hex-grid civ game + crafting game + choose your own adventure story. I love all three genres so I was thrilled to find them nicely mixed together in such a relaxing and fun to play title.

Positives:+ Many ways to solve challenges! Maybe only half of the challenges in the game solved by combat- the other are solved by a myriad of other challenges that rely on other character skills, such as Social, Tactics, Hunting, Sickness, Hex, and Physical challenges, as examples.
+ Choose your own adventure stories are great! I love actually being able to influence plot-lines by making varied choices. There are also many choices available only under certain conditions- and the game shows you how many fall in that category, making you always wonder what else you can unlock or accomplish to gain more choose your own adventure choice possibilities.
+ You get attached to your townsfolk. As they gain experience their stats “level” on their own dependent on class, which may or may NOT raise their level. I actually ended up really liking this feature because it means some townsfolk get ahead of others. Also, there are many classes, but only 3 are widely available for selection when your children grow up to adulthood status: this means that uniquely classed characters are coveted and valued. I also love continually learning about new classes in the game- for instance, the “ghost” class.
+ The challenge-solving card game turned out to be more strategically complex than I may have originally given it credit for. I actually look forward to playing the card game, though it can be a bit time-consuming (I recommend turning up the card play speed feature in the options)
+ Fun gear crafting: rewarded for experimentation, and you really feel the boost in strength when you craft and equip even one or two pieces of nice gear.
+ Crafting food is actually fun: your group gets stat bonuses for each type of unique food they carry, up to 10 types, so you actually want to make that beef stew!
+ “Research” in the game is accomplished primarily by CRAFTING useful items, and secondarily by performing quests. I appreciated such a unique mechanic.
+ Long-term goal accomplishment. You have to play through the game multiple times to unlock everything.
+ I personally enjoyed the “flavor” of the world, which includes rife “magical issues” and spirit/ demon presence to serve as choose your own adventure style choices

Both Positive and Negative:+/- While you can save and re-load the game at will, you can only re-load from your last save point, and no further back. This means you cannot easily un-do any early game inefficiencies. However, I actually ended up appreciating the mechanic- I could save before difficult points and re-load if my beloved characters died, yet I still felt the game was “live” and the re-load mechanism was natural. Note that after winning the game the first time through (which does not take terribly long), moving on to a new game necessitates ending your current play-through and moving on from your current party into a completely new game in order to access new un-locked content.

Negatives:- The game encourages re-play and has a huge amount of re-playability built into it in the “game leveling” feature: however, I feel the amount of repeat content (limited new content) as you progress can make the game inevitably feel “grindy,” which may inhibit how much re-play actually occurs.
- At times the story text can be written rather oddly. I actually really enjoy the colloquial nature of how the author wrote the texts, but certain grammar or wording errors stick out and affect the experience.
- There are times when resource management becomes cumbersome. I found later game I was spending a good amount of my time just micro-managing food acquisition and item creation and assignment instead of adventuring.
- At higher levels, facing lower level monsters can get repetitive. Fortunately the “auto contest” feature comes in handy for this. But after a while the player still feels a bit like “man, more spiders?”
- I personally felt the game could use more basic resource types, since crafting and experimenting with recipes is such a core part of the game. (I recognize why they capped it though: research is required to unlock resource farmability, so they did it for game-mechanic purposes, but I still felt after a while I was yearning for new types of resources to be found.)
- Because the game necessitates abandoning an older game to play as servants of a new god, it can be a bit of a bummer leaving an old tribe of well-established villagers to start over as a few rag-tag ill-equipped newbies

There are times when the game feels like a $20 game and not a $50 game. Well, it is a $20 game, and not a $50 game. But for the price, I got an unexpected amount of fun out of it.

Who this game is for:People who like “choose your own adventure” style text reading, and who like resource management/ crafting games.

Who this game is not for:People who don’t like to read text, people who want animations or high end graphics.

Overall: 9/10. I highly recommend “Thea: The Awakening!”

reviewText:
Thea: The Awakening - Wow!

Okay, you want more, fine!

T;TA is a fantastic game by a tiny studio called MuHa composed of former CD Project Red developers of Witcher fame.

There. No? You want more? Fine!

It's a game set in a post apocalyptic middle age setting with Slavic folklore as it's base. You are a re-awakened god or godess trying to regain entry into your pantheon. You lead a village, but not like Populous or Black and White, but as a silent pusher of buttons or something like that. Anyways, your villagers are trying to survive, while you grow more powerful and figure out what happened.

This game is part 4X-lite, RPG, Roguelike, survival and.. wait, that's not enough? How about MMO styled crafting! That should be it. Your villagers have names and jobs. You care about each and everyone. You grow your village, explore the world and gain knowledge and experience. As you regain your strength, your villagers advance. There are 8 possible gods with their own stories. There are several main quests you can do to win too. Lots of monsters, events, mini-quests to discover. There are recipes for just about anything.

There are many types of encounters and combat is not the only way to resolve them. SOmetimes it's not the best way either.

There is one drawback, and it was for me when I first started. What is it you ask? The card combat and situation resolution. Once you figure it out, you will look past it. If you can't, the auto-resolve is pretty spot on.

Anyways, this is a fantastic game from an amazing studio for a very reasonable price. Lots of replayability to be had. Support too.

If you are uncertain, check out the eXplorminate review for it.

Otherwise, go and get it now....

reviewText:
Key supplied by developer for review.
======================================Thea: The Awakening (Read on for the full review!)
======================================
TL;DR:
Being part strategy-game, part board-game, part RPG, part survival game, and more; Thea: The Awakening is a charming, qualitative, and refreshing addition to its many genres that has something to offer almost everyone. This game is absolutely worth your time.

======================================
Pros:+ Graphics: Familiar, cozy, easy on the eyes. Runs well.
+ Audio: Simple, effective sound effects. Great music.
+ Narration: Very good. Reminds me of old P&C/hidden object adventures.
+ Tutorial: Extensive, simple, not as daunting as you would expect.
+ Genres: A well executed mishmash of genres is always a plus!
+ Depth: There is a multitude of mechanics, events, and playstyles.
+ Controls: Efficient hotkeys and mouse interaction once acquainted.
+ Story: Fun, well written lore, dialogue, and events.
+ File Size: A game with few assets that uses them well. Small and quick download.
+ Progression: Whether research, equipment, or units, the 'RPG' mechanics are fun.
+ Bugs: What bugs?
+ Everything else.

Cons:- ...Uh...um...hm...*scratches head*

Neutral:+/- Hover elements in UI like to stick, queuing of actions is hit and miss. No big deal.

======================================
Introduction:Hello and welcome to Thea; the most badass thing you've ever looked at! While not truly a 3X or 4X game, it has a lot going for it, and that is going to be the most easily made comparison in terms of how it feels and plays. Let's dive into more detail.

Gameplay:In Thea: The Awakening, you are a freshly awakened deity, powers diminished, desperately clinging to your hold to this world and your followers, so your goal is to lead your followers to victory and establish your place in the world once again. You start with a nice, simple tutorial to get you going with actual experiential learning, while the help text that will pop up along the way will provide more in-depth information on the mechanics involved. You start with a set amount of villagers, on a set difficulty, with two of the gods to pick from. Each god or godess has their own bonuses, which are unlocked through gaining experience in your campaigns with them.

Both movement and combat are turn-based, with movement being tile or hex-based, and combat being card-based. If you don't want to optimize your combat results, or deal with the tedium, you can have the game auto-resolve it for you. You can gather two materials at your village, a food and building material, and you can send an expedition party out to gather specific materials while camping. Materials enable you to construct, cook, and craft. Your expedition party is a major part of your progression, though, as they are primarily how you fight, loot, and encounter events...all of which can provide you with more advanced or rare materials. It doesn't end there, though! Villagers can also progress individually, gaining stats as they level up, and better equipment will only serve to augment this growth.

There are many ways in which you can choose to deal with the start of your game, as there are many options for gathering materials. When a child grows into a villager, you can choose what their specialty will be, and you can even pick a default focus for your village when starting the game. Of course, you are going to need some of everything to progress, but this game is still friendly to multiple playstyles. It is also possible to get through encounters without fighting
date:
which can offer greater rewards, and less risk to your adventurers.
As a Torment fan, all I can say is: awesome.

Most of the options you choose to respond to an event with in Thea will involve combat, though, because you still have to 'battle' your way through sickness, social diplomacy, traps, sneak attempts, etc. The combat is tactical, card-based, and fun. You have two phases in which you place your cards in your most ideal order, left to right, and then two fight phases where damage is dealt in that order. You have plentiful options for how you want to go about doing this, from control, disable, buff, and debuff. At times this can be very fun, especially when an evenly matched enemy throws out a curveball or a good turn, and you have to respond well to get through it. At other times, you have a relatively strong party fighting a relatively weak party. Thankfully, you can auto-resolve the combat in these types of situations.

There is an impressively massive array of creatures, equipment, materials, events, points of interest, entertaining things to read, and options in this game; and all of it makes for a wildly engaging, fun, tactical experience, with a skillfully intertwined list of genres to keep anyone happy. RPG-esque turn-based combat and character progression? Check. Board-based strategy and settlement progression? Check. An almost choose-your-own adventure style event system? Check. An actually engaging story concept, lore, dialogue, and event writing? Check. Resource management and survival? Check. It even approaches being able to be labeled a god game.

Thea offers something for any number of genre fans to get absorbed in, and enjoy all the while.

Graphics:Between the colors, map, models, textures & FX, smooth little animations, actually immersive painterly art, and a UI that is easy on the eyes, there's little to dislike here, and whether you will like it or not will be readily apparent from a few screenshots.

Audio:Not only is it very good and fun, but I've yet to find the background music to get repetitive. Sound effects such as attacking or event notices are satisfying. Narration is not only nostalgic, but qualitative. There is also very little you could dislike here.

Conclusion:Unless you are an FPS, real-time combat, or action combat purist, this is a game that offers so much for such a small price. I can easily recommend it at full price. I would still recommend it at full price if it was 60 dollars.

reviewText:
Note: This is a recommendation for players who can look past some UI clunkiness and a few tedious aspects.

Thea has a combination of features I've never experienced in a game. The map looks like it plays as a 4X game, but movement across the world is about where the similarities end. The player never expands beyond their initial settlement. The settlement is more a base of operations. The villagers in the settlement craft tools, weapons and armor based on the resources that collect and recipes they unlock with research points. The research points are mostly gained by crafting, but also gained from the text adventures and battles encountered throughout the world. It's cool in this regard, because it feels like the learn by doing.

The player send out a party to collect more resources and find places of interest. The game can be won by following a series of quests. The card game used to resolve conflicts plays out fairly fast and is pretty fun. There are enough choices to give the player ample opportunities to affect the outcome.

The main problem is the user interface. There are several aspects that just require too much clicking around and switching screens. Crafting, checking the villagers equipment and assigning new items can get tedious. Also, it would help if there was a roster screen where the user could compare the skills of all of the villagers right from one screen.

I like how the day / night cycle changes how the game plays out and makes the world a little more dangerous.

If players can overlook some UI problems they'll find a game that doesn't really feel like other strategy games out there. You can find my full review here.[www.oneguytoomanygames.com]

Early Access Review

Just scratched the surface but it's worth a look at 4x/rpg fans.
Stable and reasonably feature complete for EA standards.
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=DHMvL0pD-Xo
Part rpg, part strategy and part CCG, all blends together rather well. New games start with a choice of god, each having alternate stats and abilities which level-up further through playing, new god options also unlock for future rounds. Several map sizes can be chosen, along with selecting a primary village focus. Tutorial walks through the basics which involves setting up towns for harvesting and crafting while the expedition squad starts exploring for treasure and subquests. Squads can be geared up with the loot found and forged. Battles involved the CCG mentioned, which was rather in-depth. Don't enjoy cards? Able to automate battles which speeds things along and allows focus on the rpg elements.

Lots of random events happen, I'm sure some are tied to time of day and seasonal changes. Decent looking game overall. Based on the unity engine it supports 4k+ screen resolutions and the standard range of quality settings. No options were available in-game at the moment. Controls were mouse driven, no complaints with the user interface. Laid out well and fonts all readable at higher resolutions, which included quest text (huge plus). Probably the biggest downside is the inital load time, once you are in-game they are not a problem so it's just the nature of the beast/genre.

Will update/edit my recommendation later, hopefully still helps. Cheers folks.

reviewText:
Thea: The Awakening is a turn based game that seems to borrow a lot from roguelikes and 4X games, as well as being very detailed on the management of your group. With events and quests that will help immerse you and a refreshing slavic mythology to break up the constant western mythology everywhere.

You are in control of a small group of survivors who need to brave the hostile world and survive and for this you get a very detailed, in-depth control over them all. Every piece of equipment can be custom-made within certain limits provided you have the materials to do so, and you can manage the equipment of all your warriors, your workers, and everyone else in town too. Of course, this can get overwhelming and the interface may appear cluttered at a time (Tip: If it is, uncheck 'equipped' to not show equipped items in the item list), but that is a small price to pay for the function of being able to customise everyone to your liking. You do not settle any more villages, instead sending out expeditions to gather resources and bring them back home. These expeditions can stay out as long as they have food to stay out safely to ultimately can bring back treasures and resources, clear out monster nests, or work on quests.

You gain experience and technology through quests and fighting, so it is a good idea to keep going around to find more with your expeditions, but at the same time you will need to balance the need for tech points with the need for resources. It gets fairly complex, and with a large amount of resources there are a massive amount of options for your strategies to lead to victory or defeat. This comes with a few issues as well, namely things you can find or do that are just not as good as others, or the unlocking of a resource that is not anywhere near you to gather. With limited tech points to spend on these, you will need to be sure of what you want and then plan around getting it, preferably with a contingency plan, or you will end up directionless, with random equipment looted from the enemies, and no real battle plan. And this takes some knowledge of the game before you can be reasonably expected to do well at it.

Combat, and any other challenge is done through a cardgame. At first it is a difficult and complex one, but with practise it quickly becomes clear how it works and what ability is a good idea to use when. There is a button to skip it if you just can't wrap your head around it, and it will automate it for you behind the scenes, which I have found to be a blessing when something trivial attacks you, or when you're just not feeling up for it at the moment.

Not all is great though, balance is a bit difficult to find, with some weapons being flat out better than others, and nearly all non-human characters just plain being better than your human survivors. As well as some resources just plain being inferior to others, while yet others still are so incredibly good that a deposit nearby your settlement will almost guarrantee you'll win. It can use some work, but it's not too big of a deal and doesn't hurt your experience too much.

With a large amount of events - Many of which I've not even seen after 17 hours of play, Thea: The Awakening is going to keep you busy for hours, and even though it may have its flaws, its strong points and the detailed events of slavic mythologic origin by far outweigh them and make it a very worthwhile game to play

reviewText:
This game is pretty original and hits all the right buttons: It's addictive, fun and challenging with a high replay value.

It's basicly a roguelike 3X game. Why not 4X you ask? Because it only has the eXplore, eXploit and eXterminate parts. There is a very small part of eXpand in that you build up your main settlement and attract new villagers, but you are restricted to one village and can't expand its borders like in for instance Civilization or Age of Wonders.

You play as a re-awakened god or goddess in the world of Thea, which is just recovering from an era of utter darkness. Your goal is to help the few people who still kept their faith in you survive and rebuild what they've lost while also trying to figure out what happened in the world that caused this darkness.

At the beginning, the game seems pretty restricted and simple because of the missing of the 4th X: You build weapons, armor and buildings with the materials that your expedition brings home, which in turn generates research which unlocks new materials, buildings and crafting recipes.

However, after you horribly fail the first few attempts, you start to notice how deep the game actually is. Do you want one large expeditionary force or multiple smaller ones? If you bring along a lot of gatherers in your expeditions, you can rapidly collect that valuable steel, but your wood and vegetable production in your village will suffer.

The game is also very clever in the way it handles conflicts. Most conflicts can be resolved in a number of ways depending on your expedition composition. You can not only fight a pack of wolves traditionally, but you can also opt to hunt them if you've got a few people with the proper hunting skillset. If you have a few intelligent people with herbalism and medicine skills, you can choose to just set traps for the wolves with poisoned meat.

These conflicts (named Challenges by the game) are all played out using a card game that is part luck and part skill. I'd say it is more skill-based than Hearthstone for instance.
The cards are the people in your expedition (or village, if it's under attack) and the stats and abilities on those cards are determined by the type of encounter.

During fights, the Damage statistic (which is mostly determined by strenght and the damage of your equipped weapon) will determine, you've guessed it, the amount of damage a card can do. However, during social challenges, damage is determined by the character's Speech skill. That beefy warrior with the giant two-handed axe can suddenly be completely useless if you're trying to convince a group of slave traders to let go of their cargo.

It's a very interesting system and it makes party composition extremely important, as you never know what's around the corner.

When you (inevitably) meet your demise, you are awarded a score based on all that you've done and the difficulty modifier. This score is then added to the experience of the god you've used, unlocking extra passive abilities. When any god reaches level 3, you will unlock a new god with a different playstyle. I enjoy this system, it gives a sense of progression and although the gods' abilities seem subtle at first, they have quite an impact on the way you play.

Additional things that I like are the art style used (the cards are very pretty), the music and the setting. You will encounter very unusual creatures that you may sometimes recognise from the Witcher series, as both games take inspiration from the same mythology.

All in all, I highly recommend this game, it's a lot of bang for your buck. And you will think about what you did wrong that cost you that precious Crafter's life long after you've shut down the game.

Out-freaking-standing. I love so many things about this game -- let me list them (while trying to keep superlatives to a minimum):

1. They broke out of the vaguely-western-European-medieval fantasy setting. Thank Nyarlathotep for that!

2. DEEP crafting system. I'm a loot hound so this really appeals to me.

3. Insanely detailed character stats, which leads to

4. MANY WAYS of overcoming challenges! Tired of your 2-hp wizard getting KOed by a kobold? In Thea, you can tackle enemies head-on in a brawl OR using a wide variety of other skillsets: tactical, social, magical, physical, mental... Often you get the chance to choose from 2+ challenge types. So you know what? You can create a party of specialists who can go out and kick a** on their OWN TERMS!

5. There's an interesting research tree. Brushy (lots of paths) rather than deep (usually limited to 2 levels, rarely 3).

6. The writing's pretty good -- which surprised me, considering how much other reviews grief on it. Yes, there are some odd anachronisms but nothing that made me suspend my disbelief.

7. Card-based tactical combat! Hearthstone it ain't, but there's sufficient depth that fights can get pretty thinky. Especially when you're overmatched.

Negatives:

1. I really resent the single-settlement limitation. Maybe for Xmas we can get the opportunity to set up a second settlement -- just make it have INSANE levels of input (like 1k wood, 500 stone, 15k food...)

2. Random events WILL kill your characters. It's gonna happen. Don't ragequit. This isn't an RPG. Sack up. And this leads us to...

3. Additional characters seem VERY hard to come by. I'm 80 hours into a normal-difficulty game and I have MAYBE 16 people (and a wolf). Now, this fits with the whole humanity-on-the-brink-of-extinction motif, but I feel constrained in my exploration of the different classes and character types. So get this: people are your most critical resource! Plan accordingly.

4. Map sprawl: resource-gathering teams have to go a LOOOOOOONG way to get a few key materials. That's reasonable but I really don't like spending 5 or so turns just hitting the End Turn" button.

5. No directions/instructions. Like
date: virtually nothing. So if you aren't willing to figure it out on your own
recommended: wait a bit and hope the devs hire a copywriter.\n\nALL IN ALL -- this is the best game I've played since Fallout 3. Enjoying it like crazy (writing this on 3.5 hours of sleep because of this darn game...)"

First and foremost: It is a wonderful game so far. Already beat it once after various playthroughs.

The game is well developed so far, you advance your village through resource gathering, crafting and a few types of buildings to construct.

If you want a 4X-lite game with and interesting combat mechanism and resource gathering, DO BUY!.

reviewText:
Off the bat, I want you to know that just about everything in this game comes together in an amazing package. You craft because the fighting is so fun, you fight because the exploring is so fun, you explore because the looting in this game is so fun, you loot because the crafting is so fun, you craft because the fighting is so fun, and you did that whole cycle because advancing the story and raising a group of survivors into a hardened army is so fun. Many far greater budget games with far greater hype only manage to make one or two of their systems truly great, while the rest of the game act strictly as support. This is not the case with Thea.

So what is Thea? Thea is a strategy game where you attempt to guide a ragtag band of survivors in a post-apocalyptic world. At first, you will be trying to stabilize your situation with enough food and fuel to not starve. Later, you will explore the world to attempt to find better ingredients to craft into ever-better gear. As time goes on, enemies get fiercer and quests get harder,but you are racing against that with your own technological development.

The best part of Thea is that you are never playing the game on auto-pilot. The combat system is *excellent*. It is never easy to figure out a best way to equip your party, but it is apparent you need a mix of specialties. When you're sitting at the card game, looking at the board in a close battle, it is always apparent you need to do something crafty... but it's rarely apparent whether you'd want to be crafty by putting down a big, well-shielded blocker, confusing an enemy to stall its turn, or go on the offense. Everything matters in the card-based minigame - how your hand is dealt, when you play your cards, which cards you play and hold, and what stat you play your cards for. Even hours and hours through this game, after I've played and replayed sections, I'm still finding myself putting down a bigt 2-handed hammer fighter against spiders, only to have him caught out without a shield for the Spider Queen's attack because the computer played its tactisc in a way I never expected.

All that said, Thea does have some flaws that bear mentioning, All 3D models in this game come from Unity... which means all the characters are disgustingly ugly and generic. Fortunately, there are not very many 3D models of characters, and you don't have to look at them very closely. Battles are played with drawn cards, and special events have a 2D picture. The question, of course, is why have the 3D models at all if the game's 2D is so much more beautiful than the 3D. The overworld map could've easily been purged of the ugly 3D Unity models with some clever abstract represenation in 2D.

The writing is also flawed at various points. The dialogue of the game is tone deaf. Here it is, trying to tell me an epic story of heroism, betrayal, monsters, and gods, but the language of the dialogue makes everyone sound like a modern teenager trying his best to simulate wit. This pulls me out of the epic storyline every time I reach the dialogue box.

Still, good game? Yes. Would I recommend? Definitely. Will this drain hours and hours of your life? It should.

reviewText:
One of the most interesting games of 2015. Interesting in a way games like Planescape Torment or Sunless Sea are (although the quality of writing in Thea may not be quite on par with those two). The fantasy post-apocalyptic setting, based on slavic mythology, is intriguing. The world feels strange and hostile, learning it's workings is engaging.
The gameplay blends 4X strategy (well, 3X really, you won't be expanding beyond your village in Thea), Choose Your Own Adventure gamebook style events, branching story with multiple endings (you can ignore the story altogether though, and win by achieving set strategic goals), crafting, rpg-like gearing, and card-based challenges. Oh my, what a surprisingly well put together mix!
Card combat is probably the weakest part of the game. Though it requires some degree of tactical thinking, ultimately it becomes a chore, except the most challenging encounters. Hopefully auto-resolve feature is entirely adequate. Another bugbear is that the game may sometimes feel grindy, leveling/unlocking gods in particular may've been faster.
Inspired by games ranging from King of Dragon Pass to Witcher, Thea's most important influence may be Civilization: it absolutely retains the one more turn" feel to it.

Oh and kids are a resource in this game. You can use them to lure spooky monsters into traps
recommended: trade spare children to orcs or just throw them away

reviewText:
Early Access Review

I have been waiting for months for Thea to be released and so far it has exceeded all my expectations. The developers - a tiny indie English-Polish team - have come up with very original and addictive gameplay that combines survival, 4X and RPG genres to create something pretty spectacular.

There is an huge amount of strategic and tactical complexity to the game. While you start with simple goals of surviving, you will soon be preoccupied with setting your villagers to work on various projects as you send off parties to scavange for resources to develop and defend your village. You will unlock new crafting materials to build up your tools and weapons, while confronting increasingly difficult roaming monsters and other challenges. As you explore the surrounding area, the backdrop of Slavic mythology provides a immersive narrative to the whole gameplay through encounters and random events that occur.

The card-based battles are good fun - they unfold in a logic way which allows for plenty of thinking to look for ways to defeat your enemies through clever use of tactics (the same system is also used to resolve various other non-violent challenges). It has all the 'feel' of a Heroes of Might and Magic battle.

The UI is intuative and the tutorials straightforward - it is easy to jump straight in, especially if you are familiar with Civ-style 4X games.  The Early Access status of this game doesn't detract at all. I encountered only a couple of minor bugs after 8 hours of play (eg. sometimes the music enters an endless loop). I consider it to be much more complete and bug free than many major games on full release. Thea is very reasonably priced for what it is. I know that I'll be playing it for a long time to come, and that so far I have only scratched the surface of this brilliant game.

reviewText:
Disclosure: Thea: The Awakening was played on retail code provided by the developer.
You can read the review with images and captions at Vox Ludicus[voxludicus.wordpress.com].

---------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------

In Thea, you play the role of a god stripped of its divinity, a once powerful being now relegated to dominion over a dozen villagers. Your objective is to restore yourself to power and remove Thea from the somber period it is now in, just awoken from an era of darkness. Drawing elements from 4X, trading card games and roguelikes, the main question I asked myself when I first started playing was how these elements would come together. Twenty hours later, I have a verdict.

As you start the game you are immediately greeted with the choice of one out of eight different deities, of which only two are initially unlocked. The game has a progression system where you can level up and unlock new bonuses and traits for each god as you play with them, as well as other members from the pantheon. The tiers you unlock with each deity grant you lore-appropriate bonuses: Horos, Lord of the Night and Master of the Moon, grants boons to his followers that allow them to perform better during the night and in stealthy tasks; while Mokosh, Mother Earth, facilitates the gathering of resources and food for her followers.

Each new run features a unique landscape, with your village having access to random types and amounts of resources. The game is, essentially, divided into two distinct parts: managing your village and your expedition(s). While you can scavenge resources and treasure with your expeditions, by camping and gathering on the map or acquiring it via events and battles, your village will be responsible for the steady income of fuel and food. It is a functional hub, where you can bring the resources and items your expeditions find for storage or use in crafting and construction.

The crafting system is elaborate and tied-in with another strategic element: research. As you complete events and battles you gain advancement points and experience points – while the latter will improve your villagers, advancement points allow you to unlock new buildings, different types of craftable items and “discover” new resources, which then show on your map and are subject to gathering by your expeditions. These advanced materials yield better crafted and constructed objects: a pasture that is built with simple components yields less meat than one constructed on materials that are further down the research tree.

Your expeditions will handle the exploratory part of the 4X (which is actually 3X, as you can’t grow your village) and are a compromise between the usual exploration in 4X strategy games and Thea’s survival and roguelike elements. You can only walk over a small amount of tiles in a single turn, and each turn consumes your party’s food – which when varied and plentiful also offers bonuses to their attributes. The fog of war is dictated by a day/night cycle, as is monster behavior – you can expect added aggression during the night, be it directed at your expedition or your settlement. Completing quests and battles grants you a global amount of experience, which then levels up your villagers – in the settlement or expedition – assigning them random attributes according to their designation (Warrior, Gatherer, Craftsman, etc.).

Combat is where the card aspect of the game comes into play. Before you draw any wrong conclusions, you don’t collect cards or build a deck – they are merely a representation of your villagers. Combat itself can take on many forms, some of them not necessarily lethal: your social interactions, such as trying to convince or intimidate someone, will be played in the same way as your fights, debates, physical tasks et. al., each time tapping into different attributes of your characters and setting them as the primary offensive and defensive attributes. While you can’t necessarily solve every conflict with a debate or in a sneaky manner, most quests have multiple solutions that you can choose according to how you’re role-playing or the strengths of your party: the Orc warrior that joined your group might make for poor conversation, but in turn the social interaction will allow your silver-tongued medic to shine.

The game’s setting immediately struck me as unique: inspired by both Slavic mythology and Tolkien-esque fantasy literature, you are as likely to meet an Orc chieftain as you traverse Thea as you are Baba Yaga or a Striga. The lore is well crafted and throughout the several pages of dialogue and interactions I had with the most varied creatures – benign (and malign) demons, dragons, witches and elves – the attention to detail from the Polish developers was evident.

Events are more or less independent from one another, though there are specific event chains – the main quest in particular – that can last throughout your entire playthrough. While some seem to appear with a certain frequency early on, for the most part the discovery of events and quests, much like the game’s geography and your party members, is procedurally generated. Your group’s attributes – of which there are dozens – and your previous actions will often unlock additional conversation/interaction options and allow you to solve quests in varied manners, allowing even repeated quests to have unexpected outcomes.

Now is where I apologize for the overly descriptive review and explain what I intended with it. If it hasn’t become clear from what you read, the different systems in Thea – the exploration, the village management, the crafting, the research system and the combat – do not only come together in a cohesive manner, with purpose and intent, but are introduced in the game in elaborate and developed ways. None of these mechanics feel unnecessary or shoehorned, and even less so do they look like side-thoughts or are they casually implemented.

That’s not to say Thea doesn’t have its share of flaws. The UI takes a while to get acquainted with; the difficulty isn’t forgiving, and I died several times before making decent progress into the main quest; the fact that your character can strike out at two different enemies – the closest to his left or to his right – adds an unwelcome element of surprise in a game that otherwise downplays RNG in favor of strategy; and it doesn’t cope too well with its earlier segments, which become boring after you’ve already played through the game – to your death or success – multiple times.

Thea isn’t a game for everyone. It takes the natural complexity of well-done strategy games and adds a layer of roguelike to it – something that might be appeased if you play with the save function on, a travesty I did not commit. If you’re willing to be challenged, if you want to venture into a world with unique lore and characters, if you don’t mind starting over and over and over again, Thea: The Awakening might be just the game you wanted: a strategy roguelike which values forethought and rewards caution, with plenty of progression systems to incentive your return to it, and something entirely different from what I’ve recently seen released.

reviewText:
Some really good things here.  The game itself is a really interesting take on the RPG and the background is fantastic.  It is just such a pity that the interface and game layout are so terribly stuck in the 1980s.

Good:
1. Great atmosphere
2. Interesting approach to resources and building makes choices important.

Bad:
1. Save game function is just terrible.  Either remove it altogether and play roguelike for real, or make it useable.
2. Managing character inventory and party loot is just awful.
3. The starts are not even vaguely balanced.  There is such a thing as a 'hopeless' start - in fact it is very common.  Get used to starting, looking around, and then wiping the save.  Totally tedious.
4. The research tree impacts far too little on play.  Loot will generally exceed research discovery, making it rather pointless - especially with the difficulty in gathering distant resources.
5. Bigger is pretty much always better.  More people equals win.

Thea was fascinating for the first play through (which was about 120-150 turns).

But: the following playthroughs I just cannot get invested into.  So many things I've seen before, and only one or two gems that I find occassionally.  It just isnt enough for me to spend the time on - I find my frustration exceeds my enjoyment.  The game's faults exceed the value of seeing the content that I didn't experience before.

Interface improvements would perhaps prevent me feeling like I've been struggling with the game itself, rather than facing the wonderfully interesting challenges of the world.  Immersion was destroyed by frustration.

I rate it an 9/10 for a short experience, but I just cannot bring myself to want to play it again, so overall a 3/10.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Thea: The Awakening is beautiful mixture of turn based strategy, rpg and card game set in dark fantasy world with brave move from developers to give it slavic mythology theme.

Before starting up a game, you can chose a god you want to play with ( at start only chose from 2 playable gods, rest you need to unlock by playing game).
While trailer didnt reveal much of a gameplay, I really expected some elements of Black&White god powers, but that is not the case here. Every god have unique abilities that will help your followers in some way, but beside that you will play it as turn-based rpg strategy with card combat mechanism. So dont expect throwing lightnings,fireballs...

Game has very deep and rich story and atmosphere that will surely meet all needs for all type of gamers.
I must say that it is a bald move from devs to put slavic mythology as game theme, but I am glad since there are no games with it, and people may learn something more.

Graphic is neat, awesome textures and models, good optimized that will run ok even on wooden computers.

Sound has beautiful music, follows deeply gameplay and most enjoyable to listen. However I would like some more voice acting, not just plain text to read.

Overall;
If you are in any type of games I wrote above, you must try this. Best thing there is that it is totaly replayable, guarantee hundreds of hours to play.
I usualy criticize prices on indie games, but this game is totaly worth 19,99 with what it has to offer.

Graphic:      8/10
Sound:        8/10
Gameplay: 9/10

Recommended to everyone

reviewText:
This is my first review - I enjoy a lot of games but this is the first one I felt compelled to write a review for.

I've really come to enjoy this game.  It seems simple/simplistic at first but the difficulty and depth will hit you... around turn 60 or so :-)  Lot of different ways to play the game and the combat/challenge system is really creative and enjoyable.

Many games have procedural worlds - this does also of course - but Thea manages to do so in a way that really requires a different approach each time.  Read the discussions - while there are some general strategies you'll find quite a mix of people with opposite approaches doing well (or not...)

The story and quest content is also well done.  It's nice to go through a ton of quests and then at the end realize (via end game stats) you hit only 3.2% of the content :-)

Only real con is that you're on your own to figure out how the game works beyond the basics.  The user guide here on steam and the discussion forums are a big help.

reviewText:
This game is an amazing mix of so many genres.
- 4X turn-based strategy on a hex field
- RPG (30+ attributes for every character, leveling up)
- CCG (made by Gwent designer)
- Roguelike
- Survival - this is a post-apocalypse world and it's tough
- Economy: managing food and fuel supplies, not letting your high-level characters die of hunger

Features:
- Technology tree and rare resources
- Amazing deep and detailed crafting system - you can craft hundreds of different swords, shields, maces, bows out of collected resources and monster remains
- You have to make choices in equipment - your medic just can't wear armor, sword and shield at the same time because his Strength is low. A shirt and a club instead?
- Freedom in style - you can brawl through, or you can persuade your enemies to drop their weapons, or you can sneak on them, or you can hex them with magic
- Interesting and deep quest lines and random encounters with different and risky choices - do you want to try to talk sense into a dragon? Oh your social skills were not enough and he devoured your party.
- Growing team - from ~5 characters in the beginning to ~25 characters in the late-game, every which of them is as deep, detailed, dear and different as your Baldur's Gate party
- Multiple quite different classes: gatherer, craftsman, warrior, bandit, medic, witch, dwarf, elf, goblin, demon
- Mythology, gods, quests and monsters are all from old Slavic mythology, and character names are all Slavic. It should be so familiar to Witcher players
- Balance is great and I always feel that the game is tough but manageable
- You can autocomplete" battles to avoid tediousness of simple encounters and focus on development and exploration
- Procedural random-generated world guarantees replayability Civilization-style

Oh my. You've got to try it. It's one of the most non-boring and deeply engulfing games I've played."

reviewText:
Early Access Review

This game may still in EA stage but is already quite enjoyable for players who like similar genre. Can sense there will be a lot of great potentials in the finished product. The game managed to mix the greatness from games of various genres together very well but it is not really a copy\clone or an improved version of any specific game, but rather unique on it’s own.

As the game is still in EA, so there are definitely some cons that can be very annoying and affect the gameplay experiences negatively. However these could be improved as the game development progressed. So I am giving a 7.5/10 to the game at it’s current EA stage, but this game definitely has the potential of hitting 10/10 as a finished product.

All in all, this EA is definitely worth the money spent and highly recommended to people who enjoy a civilization-like game with a mix of fantasy RPG, exploration, survival, village management uilding, crafting, resource management etc. Any improvement in gameplay that will come with the continuous development after this is a great plus.

Current Cons –

Thought the learning curve of the game is not too difficult, the game is not easy either, So expect some difficulty and frequent deaths ailures especially in the first few games.

Early game can be very frustrating especially to players new to such genre as the game can be quite difficult especially with the combat. The placement of your team is too randomized in combat and there is very high chance of your weakest link like scholar, medic, workers, greenhorn warriors etc being placed at the frontline and getting slaughtered easily. So expect a lot of casualties in the early game especially when the enemy AI tend to like to ‘gang’ your weaker team. In one occasions I have 5 enemy teams continuously attacking my team one after another all in the same turn, resulting in me losing 7 out of the 10 villagers in that single turn with the only medic gone too. Ouch!.

The rate\chance of your children (assuming you still have any) growing up or random recruits joining your village is too random and too rare. In many games I only get one grown up
ew recruit after 100 turns, and that is after already losing quite a few good men. This make the game even harder as the replenishment rate of your villagers simply doesn’t catch up with the number of deaths.

The village management uilding is too simplified at it current development stage. Too few things to build\improve and too few interactions available in the village interface as most building are only providing passive bluff\produce products. Hope to see more improvement on this aspect in the future.

No option to expand\establish new village. So you are stuck with one and only village throughout the game. (But understand this may change as the game developed)

Only one savegame allowed per play through, and starting a new game overwrite that one and only save. :(

reviewText:
Early Access Review

I will probably come back to this when I have more energy, but if you like 4X with a heavy emphasis on the exploration side of things and strong role playing and narrative elements, you are doing yourself a disservice if you don't play this game. The card mechanic as a resolution method for combat, social encounters, stealth, assassination, natural disasters, etc., is one of the best, most fresh approaches to mechanics and challenge resolution I have seen in a game in, well, forever.

For a taste of gameplay (minor spoilers for one of the many, many encounters that may pop up), on my first game after a team of my village's best got eaten by a dragon and I had to scrounge up a B team to get back out in the world and start collecting/scavenging/exploring again, a pack of Werewolves decided to show up to my incredibly undermanned village. I thought I was dead, but it turns out having silver is handy in this sort of situation and I was able to shift the encounter from a combat one to a social one. It so happens that my stay at home crafting crew, who were incompetant at combat, were really good talkers.

I think that encounter had half a dozen other options for resolution that I couldn't even access (the game notes how many possible options there are that you can't choose in a note for each encounter). Even the run of the mill combat encounters with giant rats has several approaches if you have the right skills.

I think there needs to be a little bit more balancing, but the card mechanics and village development feel really solid already. Most of the craftable weapons fill a specific role that makes them pretty effective, though staves could use some love. I especially like how the survival aspect focuses on the impact of food variety, which gives several significant buffs to the villagers and expedition if they are carrying a variety of food.

All in all, it is well worth the price of admission, especially if you are a fan of RPGs and 4X style games. Even if your not, just seeing the card system in action is pretty worth it in my book. It's nice to see a developer coming up with different approaches that let players consistently apply solution other than combat.

Early Access Review

8 scrub farmers talking ♥♥♥♥ to werewolves till they turn and run. 10/10

Disclaimer: review was done after 29 hours of playing during early access, at 30/09/2015. So expect things to be fixed and/or changed. Also beware gameplay spoilers.

Jokes aside, game is pretty fun, with complex character development, which you cannot really control outside of items, but it kinda works. Combat took a bit of getting used to, but you can do some crazy stuff with it once you get the hang of it: example. Say you got scub peasants in your army and it looks pretty bad, relax doe. Put ♥♥♥♥♥♥ peasant on field, buff him up, move him in priority to attack, confuse those he wont gib, armor and counter enemy tactics. What was looking to be a grim defeat turns into a landslide victory, thanks to the smart usage of skills.

There are a lot of stats your characters can have any surprisingly most are actually helpfull. Particularly i found Willpower, conversation and magic to be top tier picks. They come in handly on so many occasions, compared to say 'animal interaction'.

Gameplay is polished, not a single crash over 29 hours played. Yes there are spelling mistakes here and there like missing ' sign or 'dead' instead of 'deed' but these are all minor. The setting is old 6-12 century slavic mythos, one that has very little market saturation, granted there is no special market demand for that sort of thing, regardless it feels very refreshing, compared to 1 billion zombi games, endless platformers and ww2 ♥♥♥♥.

One of the biggest flaws the game has is the autoresolve issues - its completely broken. You take squad of elite warriors who just took down a dragon without taking a single scratch and pitch them against 5 bees, a beyond trivial encounter by that point. Its like an earthworm trying to battle an Abrams tank. Somehow the said tank might take immense damage  or even get destroyed? Meanwhile 8 peasants somehow take down an enemy tribe they had no business winning agaist. ?????
Also slight gear balancing issues, like tier 2 fur from wolves has no practical applications whatsowhever, same with wicker, tier 3 gems etc. Heavy armors are ridiculously underpowered aswell, compared to what you get for your material investment/alternatives from different gear gain using same materials.

[Severely lacking variation for buildings, aswell as constructing additional villages and or multiplayer.]

Coming with a really small price tag, this game definitely is worth a buy and easily scores from 6/10 to 8/10, depending on personal prefferences.

reviewText:
This is the sort of game that you start for a bit of fun after dinner.   It is also the sort of game you can find yourself still playing after the sun has risen.

My first successful completion of a game was a nine-hour marathon (huzzah for holidays!)  It wasn't all spent actively playing the card mini-games.  Your success in this game can be enhanced considerably by careful consideration of your assets.  I could spend several minutes just determining who I want in my expedition and who would remain in my settlement.  Then there were the many decisions regarding items, who would get which item, how did those items enhance their strengths or plug some of their weaknesses.  Get this done and it is a matter of which goods or tasks are you setting off to accomplish.  Are you gathering some far-flung resources?  Will those resources help you craft goods to fill any gaps in your item coverage?  Do we have enough resources on hand to let the crafters build new items while the expedition fulfills some quests and drives the hordes of monsters away from your precious settlement?  These thoughts and your conclusions become even more important as you increase the difficulty level of the game.

The game randomly generates a map for your play.  You can find some games where you have an embarrassing fortuitous dispersal of resources very near to you.  Other games you're struggling with all of the critical resources far away, requiring time, effort, and considerable danger to gather them.  The latter situation is very frustrating, but it makes for a very interesting experience where one can't simply fall into a comfortable I-WIN" pattern of play eliminating any challenge with subsequent plays through.

I forsee Thea: The Awakening being a very much loved title in my collection for a long time to come."

reviewText:
An amazing atmosphere and soundtrack, an innovative, challenging and fun combat/challenge system, and replayability out the ears. It's been a while since I felt immersion while playing a game. Each session tempts investment, you will want your people to survive and thrive. Unlockable 'classes' (Gods with sets of attribute bonuses) provide progression between sessions. High difficulty. A day 1 release purchase that I don't regret.

Game system is like a combination of Civilization (hex based 4x, but without eXpand like another reviewer pointed out so 3x), FTL, and the classic RPG. You get one city only, and start with ~10 named villagers who gain experience and grow as you explore Thea. You will earn more villagers as time passes, but in short, your people are a finite resource and not disposable.

In-game events can provide positive or negative effects to your group, but so far i've not been hit with any penalties that seem like super RNG, or unfair. So it's a bit more forgiving than a true roguelike in that aspect.

reviewText: Oregon Trail meets a 4x game. Or maybe it's better to describe it as a tile-based King of Dragon Pass. Your little people are all individually named and kitted out; you can make swords for them or shirts or knives or whatever it is you feel they need. They go and have CYOA adventures or fight with cards. It's rad as hell. Do not expect an expansionist strategy game, though -- you get one city, and that is it. You can establish temporary camps elsewhere, and they can easily become self-sufficient if they're in the right spot, but they will never have any population growth and you can't build structures there either. But you WILL want camps, because there's resources that you're going to want which are not near your city, and the only way to get them is to explore or mine. It's very medieval and very good and you should buy it, alright?\n\nJust buy it.

reviewText:
A 4x Turn-Based game where you have only one city and your units are survivors with varied skills.  Your goal is to survive a hostile monster overrun world.  To do that you must gather resources that will allow you to build up your city and craft better gear for your survivors to equip.  You will have to balance sending units out on adventuring expeditions to gather resources and experience or leave them at your city to protect it and upgrade it.  The number of units available to you is very limited they are your main resource but there is no way to regularly produce them you may build upgrades that will increase the chance of units finding there way to your town and you may acquire them through events but the same events may also kill them off.   There seem to be a good number of different events and each of them has different methods of approach or retreat.   My party came upon the path of a black cat and chose to follow, it ended with my healer in a witches kettle, We fell into a cave after a cave in and chose to explore rather then try to climb out, down the path we went right at the fork and ran into a dragon, we chose to run for our lives and not attempt to steal from it or attack it.

Combat and other event challenges are done in the form of card duels, the cards represent each of your survivor units and the card abilities vary depending on their gear and stats. A combat event can lead to the death of your unit but there are ways to mitigate that possibility, Challenge events may some times be done instead of combat  your characters will be safe from death but will likely receive less reward.

When you start the game you select one of several fallen deity, most of them require some kind of accomplishment to unlock, each can be leveled up and provides different starting bonuses and seemingly have a series of events related specifically to them.


The tutorial is somewhat helpful but also bugged the dialog to instruct me on the next turn button came up after I hit next turn and indicated it was the third dialog in the chain, I hit the go back button on the dialog to review what I had missed and the game had not gone to next turn yet and the game froze there.  On my first combat the tutorial dialog came up and indicated it was 1 of 20 I hit the next button and it vanished only to reappear many game hours later after I had already gone through many advanced fights, it let me then go through the no longer needed dialog.

This is a very entertaining game recommended to fans of Fantasy, Strategy, Turn-Based, Party Management, Exploration and Variation.

reviewText:
Thea: The Awakening is a 4X survival strategy roguelike with card based resolve mechanics and strong rpg elements, and also some choose your own adventure style events and quests that happen at random. Seriously. There's a lot going on. Here's a video review of Thea based on my first impressions, or see below if you prefer to read:

http://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=573240923

Do you like RPGs? 4X strategy? Survival games? Roguelikes? Good, because I don't know which one Thea: The Awakening is and I'm pretty sure it doesn't either. All I know is it was created by MuHa games, and features a Slavic mythology setting. The story goes that the world Thea was engulfed by by a mysterious force called The Darkness. In Thea: The Awakening, it is up to you to find a way to rebuild Thea, banish the Darkness and strengthen mankind. There are 3 basic modes of gameplay in Thea. The world map, choose your own adventure style events, and card challenges.

The world map is a familiar hex grid. From here, you can manage your village and also your expeditions, which are mobile groups of people sent out to explore the world. Although I called Thea a 4X game earlier, it would be more accurate to say it's a 3X game. There aren't any expansion options. You can't build new settlements, or even grow the size in tiles of your village. Although this is missing, it is for good reason. Different tiles have different resources in them, and your units can only gather resources from the tiles in and adjacent to the village, or camp in the case of an expedition. As the village is fixed in size and can't move, expeditions are the primary means of gathering important resources. This is good because it rewards you for venturing beyond thre settlement's walls. The downside is that there isn't a lot to do each turn. Gathering, building, and crafting can all be automated, so I sometimes found myself burning away the turns waiting for something to do. It is possible to create multiple expeditions and have them do different things, but that requires manpower, which is a little rare in the early game. It is an apocalyptic world, after all.

Both the village and expeditions require food and fuel, and can be attacked by enemies. This means there is a bit of a balancing act between keeping people in the village and sending them out on expeditions. The random attacks also mean it's safer to create one big expedition than many small ones. Although this should lead to a situation where the reward is proportional to the risk involved, it doesn't really. High level crafting materials are more important than low level ones, and sources for these are often near high difficulty mobs which require more people to handle. For example, dragon bones will probably be near dragons. Sending people out to gather lots of low level materials isn't very beneficial, and there is no looming threat that requires you to grow as fast as possible. Enemy civilizations don't seem to exist, so you can take your time to grow. That said, I don't think Thea is too easy. Even on normal mode I had to deal with some character death, and there are many difficulty options available beyond that.

Although Thea: The Awakening lacks some aspects typical of 4X games, it replaces them with new features. For example, choose your own adventure style events are a common occurrence in this game. These range in complexity, with some events leading to ongoing quests, and others being simple attacks by enemies. There seems to be a good variety of events, and you often have multiple ways to deal with the problems you face.  For example, even when dealing with random mobs, I got options to sneak attack them and poison them, in addition to a straight up fight. It's beneficial to take these options, too. Fighting can result in wounds, reducing a character's health and increasing the chance they die. As there are so few characters, it is important to preserve them. There is no chance of injury when choosing any of the alternatives to fighting. The rewards may also vary depending on the chosen option. One time, a group of orcs had kidnapped a few children, and I was sent to rescue them by a demon. Surprising none, It turned out that the demon was the one planning to harm the kids and the orcs were protecting them. I could have just killed the orcs and taken the kids, but instead I used the power of my words and won a speech challenge. They handed over the children, who would one day grow into new characters, and even gave me some rare materials with demon warding properties.

Most of these events, like the orc example from earlier, are resolved through card challenges. The same card game is used for all challenge types, but different stats are used for each one. For example, weapon damage is what affects a character's offense in fighting challenges, but speech skill is what affects offense in social challenges. During the setup phase, the card minigame splits your character cards into two hands: offense and tactical. The offense cards are placed directly on the board, and can attack the enemy. The tactical hand uses a variety of abilities to provide support. For example, a character with medicine skill in a cure sickness challenge can provide a defense boost to an ally on the board. You can use the tactical hand to cause the opponent to discard cards from their hand, give your units first strike, increase their offense and defense values, confuse enemies, and even place the tactical card itself on the board. However after the initial setup phase, just 2 rounds of belligerence play out. Cards brought onto the board from the tactical hand are confused for the first round and can't attack until the second. After the second round is complete, the setup phase begins again. This goes on until either team loses.

Thea's card minigame is a very interesting way of making different skills as enjoyable and involving as combat. Due to the high level of abstraction, the same resolve mechanics are used across the board. This leads to a slight lack of variety, but only just. The varied skills of each character in the group are enough to differentiate the overall feel of the challenge types. More importantly, the character attributes are tied into the resolve mechanics in a meaningful way, and have a strong impact on the gameplay. For example, crafters might not be of use on the front line of fights, but they can be powerful in the tactical hand. My only problem is that sometimes the challenges take a long time because of the slow animations and repetition of the setup phase. Thankfully, there is an auto-resolve option to quickly deal with very weak foes.

In addition to the gameplay modes I spoke of earlier, Thea: The Awakening is advertised for its crafting mechanics. I'm not a huge fan of crafting in most games. I avoid it whenever possible, but in Thea it's a core part of the gameplay. To my surprise, I found the crafting system quite enjoyable. The way it works is that each recipe gives you the option of using different materials as substitutes, so if you don't have thread, for example, you can still make a shirt with leather. The higher the quality of the materials you use, the better the bonuses you get. Shields made of regular wood work just fine, but shields made of elven wood give a dexterity bonus. You unlock recipes through research, and you gain research points the same way you earn experience; by exploring the world and by defeating enemies. The crafting system also applies to construction, except buildings require more resources and provide different types of bonuses.

Going back to the story and setting, it feels a little generic. Although Thea claims to be based on Slavic mythology, it's more like they took the pantheon and some of the demons and threw them into a typical medieval fantasy setting. You've got the standard orcs, dwarfs, elves, and wizards running around, and the rare Baba Yaga seems more like a novelty than a c

reviewText:
This game is absolutely brilliant.  I wish I had enough free time to thoroughly describe how well designed it is for anyone on the fence about it, but I don't want to waste a moment of limited spare time I could spend playing it.  I do, however, want to give credit to these guys, as I hope they have great success with this title, they certainly deserve it.

I think this is the kind of experience I, brad wardell, and the rest of stardock were hoping Elemental would become during its early development.  This game has such a cohessive and well thought out set of mechanics it generates its own very real tension, challenge, and personality.  Where many games end up being more or less a facade; asking the player to care, but not really giving them a reason to -the product of a designe philosophy focussing too much on goals, and less on how to actually achieve them.  Thea seems to have been built from the ground up off good ideas, and has developed them to their great potential to create something with substance.

I can't say for sure whether you'll like it, you may not.  But if you're looking at it and thinking it's the kind of thing you're interested in, take my word that it is extremely well implemented and realized.  I am proud of the developers for doing such a good job, and wish them success.

reviewText:
Adding detail to my previously positive review:

Things I 100% love:
-Feel of a roguelike for an exploration and crafting game.  It's a good difficulty curve and most decisions have truly meaningful consequence, especially in the early game.
-Something of a 4-x feel without the uber-annoying aspect of micromanaging many cities.  You have one city and as many expeditions as can survive.
-Card game battles are nice.
-The research, crafting and building trees are elegant and interesting.
-The bonuses for carrying different food types mechanic is just superb especially as it interacts with all the other systems.
-The quests and events offer meaningful choices that differ depending on your party compositions
-The unlock system for races is definitely very rewarding.

Things I don't 100% like:
