reviewText: Great game, absolutely. Though a little obtuse at times, the game is very unique in that it takes inspiration from many diffrent games and blends them fairly well. The Civilization influence is obvious here, but that fades quickly into more roguelike-ish elements, and RPG elements. Villiagers matter, as does ones settlement, and figuring out how to use them both effectively is a large, well done part of this game. The card game battle system is a pretty nice touch as well, and the game does an excellent job at explaining the mechanics. The few critisisms I can reasonably levy against the game are its dated graphics (which are easily forgiven, given the indie status) and the occasionaly confusing design elements, even though the tutorial is well thought out, I still found myself getting confused when it came to combat, among some other things. It's a very good game, I recommend it whole heartedly.

reviewText:
Wow... The devs put a LOT of effort into this game, and it really pays off.

Gameplay overview: Hex based fantasy world based on Slavic mythology. You have a village and some people (who can either stay in the village and craft/build things or roam the world gathering materials, fighting monsters, solving puzzles, and completing quests. Bring back resources to craft more buildings and items to help you out. See how long you can survive in the darkness that has fallen over the world... or complete one of the many endings! (PS you can keep playing after an ending too)

As you wander around, there are many events to encounter (or have occur to you or your village). Combat is a card battle game based on your party's equipment and skills. Crafting is fairly deep with many variations of each item or building. At first glance, the game seems a little bland... but shortly after, you will realise just how deep it gets. You will want to keep exploring the magical world, seeing what comes next and building up your party with all manner of people and creatures!

reviewText: Early Access Review\n\nThea: The Awakening has hit the mark on just-one-more-turn gameplay. reviewText:
This game is great. As an old player who has been playing computer games for 25 years, it is hard to find anything truly new and exciting anymore. Fortunaly once in a while a gem comes that makes you interested in strategy games all over again.
Thea offers a new type of gameplay and a very interesting mixture of diferent genres. You have one village and must use it to its full potential to survive in a very dangerous world. There is no expansion here except camps made by your exploration party that you set in the wilderness to explore ressource nodes. Back in your village you use the ressources gathered or taken from enemies to create new equipment and improve your villagers and fighters.
The game is hard. It is considered a survival game where your village is your life. As turns keep progressing the game becomes harder and harder. It is not expected for you to win in your first few tries, so instead you progress by leveling the gods that are avaiable for choosing at the start of the game and that act as supervisors and protectors of your village.
The gameplay is great, but the art and lore are even better. The music, graphics, drawings and enconters are beautifull. There is even some voice acting, which is of high quality.
The combat is quite interesting. It may sound simple and boring at first, but has a lot of depth and strategy value. Great adition.
Yet, not everything is perfect. Some may dislike the dificulty. There also arent a lot of tutorials, which may hinder the development of some players. There is also a lot of combat, but fortunaly most battles can be solved by auto-combat. There may also be not a lot of encounters, because I´ve already seen some repeating after 5 hours of gameplay. Also, combat music is somewhat repetitive, even if great.

Totaly recomended. I´ve played 5 hours and I´ve barely touched its surface. I give it a 9.5/10.

Pros:
- Incredible world and lore.
- Inovative gameplay, with a creative aproach to turn based strategy.
- Card combat is deep and intertaining.
- Non-combat solutions to most encounters and situations.
- Great crafting and gathering system.
- Dificult but not punishing.
- Great art and music.

Cons:
- Somewhat lack of tutorials.
- May be too hard for some.
- Repetitive battle music.
- Lack of crafting diversity at lower tech levels.
- Very limited city and empire expansion possibilities.

All in all, this game is a blend of Civilization, Dont Starve, Magic the Gathering and FTL: Faster than Light.

reviewText:
Amazing game. I can't recall any single disappointment with this title, it delivered everything it promised, and more. Rare occurance nowadays, and I hardly recall anything that caught my attention for so long at a time in single player.

Of course, you have to like this type of game - I don't think it would appeal to just anyone - but in my case it fits perfectly.

What is most amusing in my opinion:

- very well-thought mechanics of conflict resolution, based on cards. I would probably change it a bit in some details (especially in case of constantly fighting very high level monsters, which regularly drastically limit tactical choices exactly just by being high level only), but it is still awesome as it is.
- frequent development, and a lot of changes and new free content
- quick bug fixes (but frankly, I can estimate it mostly by reading dev updates, because I failed to experience any bugs on my own skin ;D)
- slavic mythology;
- a lot of events (some more interesting than the other);
- quite fun crafting mechanics (though, I want even moaarr of that and hope it will be still developed and made even better!)
- It is game under development in very good meaning of this - it is perfectly playable and interesting as it is, but still there are new additions, which makes the fun even better, and urges me to still come back and check on it.

There are a few minor issues:
- late-game it might feel a little bit tedious to manage equipment of like 30-40 characters, running multiple expeditions and actually remember who you are equiping with what, and why you decided it in the first place ;)
- I do not understand balancing of events occurance chance - some seem to occur to often. While I played some games more than 1000 days, and still took only 24% of events which I experienced - in the same time, and a few events were generated literally more than dozen times, sometimes even close to each other.
- a pity that level up bonuses seem to be totally random, i'd prefer some choices in that departyment;
- when limiting active party fight team up to 12 characters in conflict, you should be able to manually pick those who fight or don't fight, in case your party is much bigger
- personally, I would prefer a little more serious language and feel of stories, now it is in many instances a little too humorous fantasy for my taste. That is pure taste issue, though.
- I personally would add tooltips on reasearching resources/weapon, to know up front what exactly I am buying (like - of, great, I can gather the best type of something now, but then I discover, that it has really, really limited use for me, as I cannot use it to build something I thought I could.
and...

But ok, I am critical by nature, and I could find many, many more issues I consider worth reworking :), but in the end all that matters is that they are mostly VERY minor, and mostly opinion/taste-based. Whole feel of the game is very positive, and I like it very, very much.

It has a soul, kudos to devs, they showed real love and passion for gaming, creating this. Money well spent.

reviewText:
This is one of the best 4X games I have ever played.  It has the best elements of Masters of Magic and Heroes of Might and Magic, with a few civilization style elements.  There is a short learning cliff in your first game, you can easily become overwhelmed by the rogue-like random encounters if you are using balanced groups and playing it safe, and those can make the game seem unwinnable.

The combat system is extremely fresh and novel, if you like collectible cards games, you will really enjoy the way party members are used.  To compare with Magic:TG, you have a deck in each combat composed of all your party members.  They are divided in half randomly, one group is your offensive deck and the other half is your tactical deck.  Party members played from the first enter into the combat, like a summoned creature, and will have stats based on what traits they have as what is gained from their equipment.  The tactical deck, however, when played must use one of their traits to have an effect like using a spell.  These can boost your in-play party members, empty cards from the opponents hand, or weaken enemy cards.  There is an auto-resolution system if you do not want to play the mini-game, and I have found it to be extremely fair so there isn't a punishment for never using the combat system.  If you are very good at the mini-game, however, you can win some battles that the auto-play will treat as a loss and you can get away with extremely risky expeditions that way.

If you are really into roleplaying story, this game has extremely well written encounters.  I enjoy reading them, and usually despise story elements in similar games.  Getting the same encounter repeatedly is pleasant, there are many possible outcomes which change based on who is present in your party at the time and what skills they have.  An encounter will show you the number of unavailable options, but does not tell you what they are or what is needed to unlock them and the number of options for most encounters is very high.  There are still some random encounters with 11+ options that I have not seen, even after clearing 2 default options.

If you are not interested in story, and just like strategy games, there are options to plow through storyline elements with minimal fluff as a default option for any storyline quest you attempt.  The NPCs are very gracious about being told to shut up and just give you the things you need without explanation.  Even on the first play through!

The crafting system is hands down the best thing I have ever seen.  At first I was disappointed at the limited number of buildings and equipment, until I realized that using rarer materials changes the appearance and statistics of the building.  You can build a smithy out of wood like normal, or build it from bones and start randomly recruiting wild animals from rats (don't laugh, a brave little rat died in a storm to save one of my veteran gatherers) to wolves and bears!  Building from more exotic materials will let you get other demi-human races from fantasy lore such as Goblins, Orcs, Elves, Dwarves, and Demons.

You are limited to only one village the entire game, however you can pack up a group of people and take them into the world to camp.  While camping, the party members there act like an extra village and can gather materials.  If you find a good location with access to basic materials like wood and food, you can leave a second camp there permanently like a second city.  The only limitation with camps is that they never build any buildings to help them defend themselves, and they can't craft new equipment for themselves.  Some other group must act as the go between, taking resources to the village and then delivering finished equipment back to them.  Children are only created at your home village, but can be carried out to your camps where they can grow into adults if you prefer.

10/10 game, I have no complaints about the game apart from wanting a multi-player co-operative mode!

reviewText:
This is the first time I have been moved to write a review on Steam.

As an RPG/Strategy game player it's not often anymore that a game pops up and captures as much of my time as Thea: The Awakening. I frequently try out non AAA games that pop up on my recommended screen and they generally are ok, but this is something else.

Without going into too much detail: The strategic map is varied, exciting and atmospheric. The tactical card game is reasonably deep, exciting, and not too repetitive. You can always auto-resolve anything stupidly easy although I think the auto-resolve is a little generous to the player.

I started out on Difficult (3/4 difficulty) and it is a genuine challenge. First couple of tries I just ran out of people by risking them unncessarily, you really do get attached to your individuals as it is very difficult to replace them. The constant struggle to keep resources coming in while expanding and doing the main quest, as the world closes in around you and seems to ramp up in difficulty over time, is extremely engaging. I bought this for £12 and keep coming back for more, I would happily have paid more in retrospect.

Looks like loads of replayability with different Gods to try, different quests, and a very random world.

Art fantastic, as is the music, more music please!

Do yourself a favour and buy this now. Do me a favour by encouraging the Devs to expand on this. Hidden gem so spread the word.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

I love this game! When first glancing at the screenshots you might expect this game to be a standard fantasy 4X, but it really isn't. The lore and story of the game is quite unique, and the main mechanics involve managing gathering materials and crafting for a single settlement. You don't build units, instead you have a number of children that age up as time progresses. Combat and other conflicts use a card mini-game for resolution, and whilst at first this may be off-putting, it's actually quite enjoyable once you get used to it. Additionally you aren't in competition with AI, instead you explore, craft, and complete quests at your own pace, which I quite enjoy.

I'm really looking forward to seeing how this game will develop, as gameplay is already very satisfying and enjoyable. I only have a few minor complaints; there are a number of typos, however they will surely be fixed with time. Additionally  the UI for moving your expeditions requires one too many clicks in my opinion, but the dev seems very receptive to feedback, so hopefully this will change in the future. Finally the auto-resolve option for conflicts is pretty much guaranteed to result in failure, but you'll get more enjoyment by manually completing the battles any way.

I'd definetly recommend giving this game a chance, especially if you're looking for something a bit different from the usual.

reviewText:
The follwing is copied from my review on pressa2join.com/thea-the-awakening-review
[Disclosure: Game Copy provided by Developer/Publisher]

Thea: The Awakening is an Isometric turn-based strategic survival game, steeped in Slavic myth and monstrosity with RPG, 4x, rogue-like and card game elements, published and developed by MuHa Games. While this is Muha games first major release they have previously created a number of flash games such as: Town of Fears, Road Wolves, Racing Toys and Zack’s Hardware. Individual members of the team have worked on titles such as: The Witcher 2&3, DiRT Showdown, GRID 2 among others. It’s also worth noting that the studio also has created the (fast becoming popular) Honey Hex Framework available from the Unity store which Thea uses.

Welcome to the world of Thea; An apocalyptic force known only as ‘The Darkness’ has engulfed the world for an age, warping and transforming the land and its creatures. Even the Gods themselves have been stripped of their power, only able to watch as their followers dwindled in the face of the horrors. Just as the last embers of hope began to fade the light returned to Thea once again, the Gods and the land awoke; the few remaining survivors are left with the daunting task of trying to rebuild and survive. There are many creatures warped by darkness and there are no heroes, monster slayers or great armies able to combat them. As one of the gods reawakened you must guide your people through the land that by day is at best; dangerous, but as night falls the creatures become even more aggressive. You must find out what happened to the world and how, as the return of the light may be fleeting.

Thea is a strategy based game that at first glance looks very much like “Civilisation” or “Heroes of Might and Magic” there are however a number of differences in gameplay and mechanics which turns the game into something unique and interesting. For starters the player only has one settlement throughout the game, there is an ability to set up small camps which can gather nearby resources and as such can act as a forward base of operations. However, players will only possess the ability to operate and defend these camps in mid to late game. Thea also has a heavy “choose your own adventure” influence in that random events will occur and often the player is given a number of choices in how to deal with this occurrence. This choice will not only effect this instance but may affect other events and possibly even elements of the main story. There are two available starting deities to play with, an additional six being unlockable each of which have different perks/abilities and therefore playstyles. Thea also features a deep and interesting crafting/research system.

Whilst there exists a number of different ways to face the challenges in the game, one of the easier ways is through combat, and indeed the combat system is familiar yet different. The player cannot train new units and is reliant on new survivors joining their cause as well as children being generated and growing up. There are a number of different types of survivor from warrior to farmer and a few more in-between. Those joining your village will already have a type, however children growing up will have a choice of what they can become, which can prove extremely useful. The combat itself is done via a card based mini-game, as are the different challenges, each with their own unique twist. The card mini-game is reminiscent of “Magic: The Gathering” and indeed as such whilst having the appearance of being very simple has a number of different mechanics in play that can change outcomes drastically. The game does have a high learning curve but the player is assisted with an excellent tutorial/help system that teaches the basics and is also available on hand upon request.

The game as a whole has a very substance over style feel to it, which in a game were mythology and lore are key is definitely the way to go. Being an isometric turn-based strategy the graphics are not the priority however the animations and textures are still extremely nice and help bring the lore of the game to life. One of the things players will likely notice is the graphics in combat as the various characters and creatures are as mentioned cards which are hand drawn in appearance, but as indicated what it lacks in graphics it makes up for in gameplay mechanics. The music and sound assets provide an excellent undertone for the game as a whole and like all good music and sound assets give the game that little extra boost.

Overall I have to say that although the game has a fairly high learning curve it is extremely interesting and rewarding particularly for those like myself who have an interest in mythology and lore. However, that being said there is still lots of nice elements that would interest 4x, RPG and rogue-like players alike. One of the biggest surprises for me was a fully customisable experience not just with the “choose your own adventure” elements but indeed the difficulty be can be completely customised to suit different play styles. Also as mentioned there is a rogue-like continual progression system so even if a playthrough ends in disaster the player will get some experience towards levelling up their chosen deity. One addition I would like to see is a multiple save system so different deities can be tried out. There is much more to the game than what I can cover here, if you like what you see check it out. Thea is completely mouse driven although I used the steam controller in my playthrough.

Overall: 8.1/10 For full breakdown, screenshots etc, please visit website.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

TL;DR: This game is simply amazing.  It's part 4X strategy, part collectable card game, with roguelike elements sprinkled in for a game that will feel familiar in many aspects, but is refreshing in both style and play.

Where do I begin?  I suppose with where I began in the game: a blank intro screen that I couldn't get past.  I posted on the forums, which was quickly responded to by the developers.  A few others were having this issue too.  Within 2 days there was a patch released which fixed this, among many other fixes/changes.  I know it's early, but these guys are updating quite often and I'm already more confident in this product than I have been many Early Access titles due to how playable the game already is.

Speaking of the game, it's great fun.  The art style and lore is based on Slavic mythology, which is unique and interesting.  This game plays like a 4X where survival will feel more random than you're used to, so be ready to get shafted sometimes (but that's half the fun of roguelikes, isn't it?) by things like God-created storms ravaging your town and people.  But if you manage to survive, you'll find that the game has quite a bit of depth to it already, including a card game battle system and crafting systems I will discuss later.

The game itself is a little micromanage-heavy, but it remains interesting due to so many options, especially when it comes to crafting.  You will be constantly trying to craft or loot better equipment to upgrade your older and newer companions with.  I've spent probably more time than I should have switching out every possible option for crafting a club for example, which gets extensive when you need multiple types of material (metals, woods, leathers, gemstones, string materials, etc.) to craft an item, and later in the game you will have quite a few options of each material, and most materials add varying amounts of stats, sometimes with unique bonuses as well.

The card game is pretty interesting as well.  I would suggest reading the tutorial for it the first time.  It's a little complicated at first, but if you've ever played a card game it will be easy to learn.  There is actually quite a bit of strategy involved for how simple it looks.  The people of your expeditions and town will be the cards you use to fight your battles, which gives it a deck-building aspect as you grow in size.  Most battles will be realistic, where your people will suffer wounds for taking damage, and can potentially die.  Some are test battles, of mental/physical/stealth/etc skills your people may or may not have.  The one good thing about the test battles is you can succeed in many parts of the game without having to risk the lives of your people, but they can be nearly impossible to win if you don't have the skills required.

One minor complaint I have is some of the text in the game seems a bit rushed.  I remember doing one event/quest where my reply to a character was something like ok cya".  "See ya"or "see you" would have been alright

reviewText:
From the darkness, a ray of hope sees my eyes flick open: I am a god. How long have I slept? A century? My worshippers, so few now, I must guide them...

For this player, 'Thea: The Awakening' has been a love at first sight affair. The player takes the role of a deity, who in turn takes the role of a group of followers. These followers have emerged from an apocalypse of darkness only to have the new dawn illuminate further perils to come. Despite this premise, set in a decidedly dark fantasy world, I cant help but think of Rick from the Walking Dead as I direct my group of survivors to scavenge supplies and fortify, survival our primary concern. I begin to grow attached to each individual in the group. I realise this as night approaches and the sunlight retreats. The dead walk tonight, not far from my settlement, and my four best fighters are out on a salvage mission. To the north my lookouts spot giant spiders scuttling through the dusky gloom. Supplies are getting low, and our resident medic may be about to have a very busy night. My non combatants arm themselves as best they can and they pray for me to guide them to dawn...

What is not to like? Buy this if you like fantasy games, survival games, games with crafting and gathering, heroes that have to eat, games where you can rename every villager and hero you own, card games, TBS games, games where combat is an option but not the only way to get through the night... This hybrid is something special. Just one turn more, right? Yeah right.

reviewText:
Mostly enjoying the game so far, and defiantly happy to have in my games library. Large scale adventure with a small village of people in a random world. Your village really is just a village with a handful of people so everyone counts, even a crow (yes I'm talking about a bird) that joins your people has it's uses.

Your enjoyment of the game hinges highly on how well you take to the card system that resolves all challenges (combat or otherwise) are resolved, in which relevant stat become the offense, defense, and special abilities rating for your villagers whom are represented as cards played from a hand. Takes a little getting used to all the stats and how they'll play out, but for those whom love that sort of thing like myself will find the options very engaging. Added to that the permadeath risk gives you some investment in challenges you might have seen before. Although there is a auto-resolve feature to quickly breeze through pushover challenges.

The story writing is solid and flavorful, with some quality world building which makes up the heart of the game. The art design is very endearing, and I like how the cards representing you villagers and their opponents go for the hand drawn/hand crafted look. Defiantly one of those game I wish there was more of, both in terms of more content for this game (which the developers are working on and adding too), and more game following this RPG, management, & strategy combo.

Big note: There is a fix start location that CANNOT be changed (where your only settlement is permanently - though you can make multiple indefinite camp sites). It significantly impacts the difficulty of the games, and can be extremely frustrating for 4X fans whom are used to picking their settlement sites and trying to optimize resources, but does give a bit FTL or Bedlam feel to it.

reviewText:
Take the hex-based map and travel of pretty much any Civ game, add in Slavic mythology and folklore, a card-based combat system, and throw in the helplessness of only one town to defend and you've got Thea. You guide a group of people looking to restore light to a world after 100 years of darkness, and you're beset on all sides by hungry animals, scavengers, demons, undead, and spirits. Like other turn-based games. you'll end up playing for one more turn until your eyes hurt because hey, you could totally clear out that abomination lair before your food runs out and your people begin to starve to death one by one as you trek back to your village hauling precious granite that you were going to use to build a proper palisade.

Pros:
- wonderful art and music
- you can talk or tactic or sneak your way out of combat and minimize deaths
- new children are delivered by storks and appear in cabbage patches, as is historically accurate in all Slavic lands
- a fresh spin on the traditional orc/elf/dwarf/mystical crystal fantasy we've been treated to since Lord of the Rings was published

Cons:
- not enough squatting or alcoholism to truly be a Slavic Middle Ages simulator
- the rogue-like one-save-slot, people-will-die, if-your-town-dies-the-game-is-automatically-over element can be infuriating to those who are more familiar with a game where you're given a few turns to get everything back from the death stack of bears and bees who invaded your coastal village and ate everyone
- some of the writing feels too snarky and smart-♥♥♥, as if Joss Whedon were writing it and EVERYONE has a witty comeback to everything that's said

reviewText:
Firstly i should explain what games i like for context (mind you i'm not saying that Thea: The Awakening is like these games). I really love city building games: Tropicos 3 and 4 are my current favorites, also Cities: Skylines. I play 4x games but i'm not that good at it. Civilization V and Endless Legends are the 4x titles i play occasionally. Dwarf Fortress is too hard for me although i like playing it. Now on to the review.

I reccomend Thea: The Awakening because it's a fresh take on the 4x genre. They pride on classifying it as a 3x game though, you manage only one village so no need for expansion here. I won't spoil the story here but i do love the mythology and i think it's a huge factor for the game.

Now in this one village that's randomly generated from the start you can gather two resources, craft equipment for your people, and erect buildings. The thing is the resources you need to craft and build stuff are scattered all around the map. The only way to gather it is to create an 'expedition', a unit consisting of some of your people, and send them on a fetch quest.

Expedition units can also do quests, hunt monsters that may threaten your village or destroy their gosh darn ding-dang lairs. This will earn you experience points to level up all your people and get you research points which you can spend on new crafting recipes, reveal new resources on the map, or get a new building blueprint. Oh and your people are divided into different classes like warrior, or gatherer, or ... the other peasants that make stuff for you, and many more. You can even have characters from other races!

Does it sound exciting to you? Does it? If it does you should buy it! If not, maybe i'm not reviewing it right because it's hella fun. I have a total of 24 hours gameplay when i wrote this review and i suspect there'd be many more because a DLC is coming.

reviewText:
This game really is a hidden gem.

It consists of an overland map upon which you gather resources, complete quests and fight enemies.

The combat, and many other tasks are carried out using a cards system, where the chance of success is determined by a range of stats.

The graphics are nice, and the sound is well done.

My only criticism would be the save system is a bit shoddy. There is an autosave which overwrites itself at the start of each turn, and the option to perform a manual save. However, you only get one manual save which is overwritten each time. This of course means that if anything happens to that save you lose all progress, I've also had my manual save overwritten by the autosave.

In the scheme of things though it's only a minor concern, and hasn't taken anything away from the gaming experience.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

This is really good. Seems pretty much feature-complete for early access. It still has some spelling mistakes and I would like to see some hotkeys but otherwise its good enough to release in this form.

Its pretty original - it reminds me a bit of King of Dragon Pass but played out on a more detailed hex based map - maybe the story telling is a little less deep but the crafting system, technology tree and character progression more than compensates for that. There's perma-death and a lot of randomness to the map so roguelike comparisons are valid too.

All fights and challenges are played out in a card battle that is sufficiently intricate to feel like you are deploying skill, but there are random elements to it too so occasionally it can feel like you've been rng screwed - I don't so much mind the way the targets are selected randomly as much as the random splitting of your cards into offense and tactics - which can leave all your best offense cards on the tactics side and vice versa. I do really like the way that there are various different types of challenge - fighting, tactics, intellect, sneaking which use the same system but different stats.

I really hope they will continue to add new events to this in an ongoing way which will really add tot he longevity/replay value. I'm not sure how close to release it is or if there are other major systems they are planning to implement, but its worth purchasing in current form already - a really unique and compelling game.

reviewText:
Thea : The Awakening is a story about god who lost his/her powers and now must guide their people in a world that is mostly under cover of darkness.

This is done by managing the progress and tasks of your worshipers as well as guiding them trough battle.

There is a base questlines you can do to win, either by advancing to certain stage or completing quests that help you regain your power. These are done by both exploring and harvesting resources and building structures.


Thea is, depending your experience, either extremely hard or simple game, mostly due it's ( on higher difficulty than normal or custom games), one save slot policy  ( normal and easier games have autosave + one normal save), meaning if your people die, they die for good , unless you crash the game and are willing to start over from way way back in game time, so the game gets fairly decent amount of challenge specially on early combat.

Finishing game or losing adds experience to your god unlocking bonuses that make further games easier with that god, and unlocking more gods. reviewText:
This is a hard game to describe, as it fuses multiple genres together in an extremely unusual way. That often ends in disaster. It doesn't in this case. In a nutshell, there was a magical disaster in the past, and you play as one of the exiled (weak) gods trying to return to the world of Thea. Being weak though, you have to act through a small group of followers. The game is turn-based.

You control all the actions of your followers, and there is a single village from where you will direct their production tasks, create expeditions, and reclaim knowledge. You can recieve more followers through random events, building structures, or your choices in encounters. Each follower can level up and be equipped with a variety of gear according to their class and weight capacity. (The equipment crafting system is deep, and you also find gear after combat and events).  In addition to your human followers, you can also rarely try to recruit dwarves, demons, beasts, goblins, orcs, and elves- there maybe more I'm unaware of.

Because Thea is such an unusual fusion, following are some PROS and CONS to hopefully show the game's strengths and weaknesses.

I must say that i was somewhat skeptical about Thea : The Awakening even after watching some gameplay videos. In the end, i bought it alongside The Witcher 3.

Long story short, I´ll spend a LOT of time playing Thea before i get back to The Witcher 3. It´s an absolutely amazing game which has surpassed all of my expectations.

In Thea, you command a single settlement of followers of a weakened God, who have to gather their strenght to survive a barren world. Each of your people have a name, a picture and a particular set of skills. You form teams and send these teams to the world, in an hex based map, to explore, gather resources or complete missions.

There lies the first of Thea´s many great features. The missions and events that your people will encounter are really well written and have many possible outcomes, which are backed by a rich lore that makes the world worth exploring.

Now, if you´re like me, you probably felt skeptical about the challenge system, or the card minigame". It was the main reason why I was skeptical about this game. But

reviewText:
This is not a 4x by any means, so if you want a Civ game, this isn't it.

What it is however, is an engrossing game with a rich narrative, and an expansive universe. On top of that it has a unique crafting system that makes you sweat, as you need to search for the best resources to craft the best equipment (weapons, armour, trinkets, the usual)

To keep it simple: You have a single town that you control. No colonists/expansion. You only really need two resources: Food, and Fuel. Building choice is limited to less than 8 buildings. You may think this is absolute heresy, however you'll spend 90% of your time managing your expeditions
date:
than using your town. With these expeditions, you seek out resources, fight monsters, explore areas, and follow the story line. As there is more than one way to win, and more than one god to play as, this game has good replay value.

Why buy it: If you like a somewhat challenging game (even on normal) that requires patience, and has great (and sometimes snarky) dialogue, where instead of worry about resource management, you focus on crafting development and map exploration, this is your game.

If you're looking for a Civ clone, standard 4x, Banished or city-management, this is not for you, which is okay, hence why it's not listed as a management" or "economy" game. This game won't scratch your Might and Magic
hoursPlayed: but it's unique enough that it'll satisfy a craving you didn't think you had

reviewText:
Fascinating game. It is always encouraging to see new games that step outside of generic formulas. The issue of 4x games for me has always been about filling that middle of the game 'void'. The beginning and end of the game is normally exciting, but the inbetween is cumbersome.

Thea largely addresses this problem by continually giving you important choices to make throughout the game. You are constantly battling for survivial and always have immediate goals to work towards. Also, by making individual characters meaningful, battles become more significant and never lose their edge.

I have found that towards the end of a game, if you are being overwhelmed, the ending of the game can be a long, drawn out process. I suggest that if you realise you are going to be wiped out, start a new game, rather than waiting for your village to die. Easier said than done... there is always this glimmer of hope that you might be able to find redemption.

reviewText: I've been waiting a long while for a game like this. Simple up front, yet with decent depth of gameplay. Thea: The Awakening is a fantasy based sim with exploreable maps and an interesting storyline. It’s like playing a pick your own adventure book on a civilizations based map full of resources, runes, monsters and treasures with characters/villagers that have adjustable and craftable stats. Battles and challenges have a magic the gathering card based feel to them yet with more simple mechanics. You only have one settlement, but if your intelligence, will, magic or strength is high enough you can do some crazy things. I've actually traded my human settlers for Orc warriors using advanced social skills, I've talked a werewolf into sharing his silver with me (he was using it to build an immunity to silver) rather than fighting him and his pack to the death, I've had my villagers become knights for an Arthurian based quest, and more. This is a great gem of an indie game and worth picking up for casual gamers and hardcore strategy/fantasy fans alike. The only comment I can say to the developers is that I wish there was a little more depth to the card based battles which offered a bit more customizable strategy. They do get a little repetitive after a while even if there are a variety of challenges/battles (they are all essentially the same). If the card game was more like the Witcher 3’s card based game I think that would be better. Likewise, only having one village gets annoying on large maps. It would be nice to be able to colonize or have the option to establish at least one or two more villages; or incorporate other races’ villages as your own in an alliance. Creating halfbreeds between races and allowing a family tree to control in your small village would be interesting as well. Let sauce up the cabbage patch a bit shall we? I would die laughing if a stork dropped off a half human half goblin baby or something like that.

reviewText:
This game is very unique. It is a board game, roughly like the settlers of catan.
On some hexagons of the map, there are resources that you can farm. You can do this through sending out a  group of villagers to scavenge the materials. But you have to keep in mind that the villagers need food and warmth. Also, the group is more prone to get attacked by many monsters that roam the world freely.
The battles are very unice and well thought out. The battles are in the form of a card game, like magic the gathering or yu-gi-oh!. It makes you think about how to utilize the abilities from your villagers in that battle and about how it can support other villagers.
The extra element of not being able to create new settlements, gives a new deth into the game. It makes you second guess whether it is a good idea to get some materials and what the group will need during their journey.
The game sets you thinking about how to survive and what the best way of doing things are. Futhermore, every game is different as the world is randomly generated. There is a fast diversity of events that all end up differently depending on your abilities and your choices of how you want to deal with it.
I would like to see a multiplayer function incorporated into this game, as it would be very interesting to be able to trade  and/or be at war with other settlements.

reviewText:
This is really a unique game that I'm enjoying greatly so far.

From the pictures of the game it may seem like any 4x game, but in reality the pace and feels to me more similar to an old school RPG, with a card mini game instead of turn based combat.
TLDR: If you like games that have RNG, RPG elements, and management, this is for you.  Pick it up, as I haven’t played a game this unique in a while.

Pros:
-Everything meshes well, from inventory management to exploration to resource gathering, you really get engrossed with the mechanics while trying to win.
-Great artwork and art style.
-The card game is challenging and has enough depth to keep it fun, without being too time consuming and complicated to the extent that you'll get fatigue from the number of encounters you'll have in the game.

Cons:  (I’m more writing this hoping the devs will gets some ideas how to make improvements)
-The writing is subpar, oftentimes throwing walls of text at you or being sort of silly.  I haven't gotten much into the main quest, but I can't say I'm very interested in the story, just more into the gameplay itself as you try to complete it.  Sometimes individual encounters will have interesting folklore or mythology to it (the game is inspired by Slavic mythology apparently) but in general I would have preferred a more concise text based storyline and a better story in general.
-The “skull” system for giving you an idea how difficult an encounter could be needs some work in my opinion.  I’d much rather have a statistic screen showing me the likelihood of outcomes (i.e. % chance you’ll win, % chance you’ll win but a party member will be gravely wounded, % chance you’ll lose etc.)  In addition, the skulls don’t really give you a good prediction of the difficulty of enemies you’ll be fighting.  I might not have played enough to see the patterns better, but a 3 skull fight sometimes surprises me as a cake walk while another 3 skull fight throws creatures at me that will guarantee to kill my entire party.
-The U.I. is in general good, but the most “busy work” time seems to be when you’re adding and comparing equipment for your individual villagers.  It needs streamlining, for instance: when I have a villager selected and look over a weapon in the general inventory I should get a box that appears that compares that item with what he has currently equipped instead of having to individually hover over each item to determine stats.  Another aspect is that all the stats numbers for characters seem to be jumbled on the screen instead of alphabetized, so the attack power of one character will be on a random spot on his stat screen that’s different from another character’s position.  In addition the production screen will state you have enough material to build a certain item when you in fact don’t, as 3 different items of the same type can’t be combined to produce something.  Though these seem kind of nitpicky, for a game like this small U.I. difficulties really add up the “busy work” time wasted.  I hope to see some of this updated in the future.
-For a game that forces you to only have 1 village, the village maintenance mechanic is fairly Vanilla.  I would like a way for you village to expand its gathering zone (while having some way to keep it balanced) as well as having different options for buildings.  Right now, you have only a few options for buildings (with a 10 building cap), and you destroy and rebuild the same buildings just with different parts to try and get a bit better buffs.

reviewText:
Genuinely impressed by how good this game turned out to be. I had it on my wishlist ever since I came across it when it was in Early Access, but I didn't follow the development. Picked it up as an impulse buy a few weeks ago and I absolutely love it.
It's a mix of 4X-ish, RPG, roguelike, card game elements and overall is a pretty original package. I've gotten 76 hours out of this game so far, more so than many other AAA games that are 3x the price.
I do have some gripes though, there seem to be some performance issues in the late game, which I presume are due to the high number of enemies on the map, villagers and items. It's not a big issue, but a bit annoying since the frames dip from time to time.
My only other gripe is that the difficulty curve is a bit off, the game starts off as being pretty difficult, you have to struggle to survive, but later on when you start crafting higher tier equipment and your villagers get a bit higher up in level, the game becomes progressively less difficult.

But those negative points are counterbalanced by the fantastic music, great art and most importantly, the very fun gameplay. I can't describe it any other way than 'you'll lose track of time' when playing this.

Overall I'm very impressed with this game, can't wait for MuHa to add more content and expand upon what they currently have.

The game mechanic focuses strongly on crafting and resource locating and gathering.  For example, units can gather resources more quickly if they have baskets, but to build baskets might require a material you don't see on the map.  So there's some frustration to try to find that resource.

Sending expeditions into the wild, they will encounter fights with the local wildlife and a cardgame creates a 1 dimensional (line) battle that becomes the majority of gameplay.  The fights are more interesting than I expected.  Units can be equipped with armor/weapons found in the field or crafted, and where the strongest units are placed can allow meat shielding with weaker units to allow a stronger unit to survive longer.

There are variations on the standard fight" card battles.  I just did a "everyone has a hangover from drinking too much alcohol
date: so they must all fight the hangover" battle!  Significant effort went into making about a dozen or so different forms of battles - so it's not all armor and dexterity and strength.  It throws enough of a twist into the game to keep it very fresh and foreign to RPG players.\n\nAdd to all that some very good dramatic openning stories and quests generated on the map or in towns
recommended: and the gameplay has wide variation that doesn't stagnate.\n\nThe stories are well written and engaging.  The stories provide multiple choice dialog but they are still very short.  That quality starts to push this game into the educational domain - the concepts provided in the stories are ethical
hoursPlayed: and provide good food for thought.  So far all the writing I've encountered has been uplifting.\n\nIt's almost like the game is a "choose your own adventure" story

reviewText:
Okay so I could write a review like: slavic mythology and piroggi for lunch 10/10! But that is really not a sufficient review so let me explain a bit why I enjoy the game and recommend it.

Positive:
I don't know many games (in fact none) that is focused on the slavic mythology with its pantheon and dark creatures and in my opinion it is lovely adapted into this game
The story makes sense and although not perfectly explaining everything still combines the gameplay with the characters etc.
Things can turn pretty bad quickly for you if you are not careful in how you proceed. E.g. if you just go out carelessly and leave only farmers and craftsmen in your village then they might die when the village is attacked  but on the other hand you HAVE TO move out to find new resources, food or items.
I like the pictures made for the characters and monsters but also for the items. You can see a lot of love for the game and the details there.
That is also true for the lore they wrote and the texts they wrote. You learn a lot about different creatures in the world and you can decide for yourself if you would like to negotiate with Orcs or if you just try to smash their skulls.
You have a big variety of food and items you can craft. Of course they have different values and there are probably only few items if you want to have maximum effect (important for the combat stats) but I just love the fact that I can cook and roast not only the mentioned Piroggi but also Leczno, Roastbeef, cooked vegetables, cooked fish, rabbit stew and a lot more (there are 3 ways how to prepare your food namely cooking, roasting and baking and I already have ~15 recipies without the baking I think). Also you have to find out what ingredients have what effect for the item. Yesterday I sat there 5 minutes just trying to find the best values between armor and a +stat for my new armor with what I currently have in stock thinking back and forth.
Personally I like the combat system because it is something different (you place your characters as cards, depending on their items and stats they will have different use in the fight) and you will have to think about your turn and what you want to do always with the risk of losing one or more of your important people.
Even though the setting is dark and it is a hard game at times, you will still find little jokes or funny things in the game making you smile.
The replayability is high because you can unlock new abilities of your chosen god as well as unlock other gods of the pantheon for your next game. Each god has other strong points so it should change the difficulty and the way you play. I also think some quests change depending on your god (can't say that for sure as I am still in my first play-through)
Negative:
Sometimes the game can be too hard because if you lose people in the beginning it will be tough to impossible to survive long enough. Later on after you have a critical mass of people you can afford to lose one or two. It'll set you back but you will survive. On the other hand thats why it calls itself a survival game as well I guess. And there is always the possibility to reload the save game.
Sometimes the combats can be a bit unfair as the fact if your cards" are in the combat stack or the support (tactical) stack is based on chance just like the type of weapon of the enemy cards. It can be a big difference if they have big cards with just "sword damage" or if they have blunt or piercing weapon effects.
I am not sure if it is planned to add more villages in the future  but so far you only have one village and you can't create more as the game progresses. Even though it is a post-apocalyptic setting (middle age style) I think it would be nice if there were other villages (blessed by the other gods e.g.) or if you could at least establish new ones later on.
Overall I think it is a great game with a lot of love. So far I played around 30 hours and I am still playing my first play-through. Also I am certain that after that there will be another one with a different god. Also important to note is that there are still things being added (like the free dlc Return of the Giants) and bugs being fixed. But even in its current state the game is worth its 20€. the only thing you should ask yourself beforehand is: Is this the type of game I like where your decisions count and influence your progression? Maybe also watch a Let's Play before you buy it but if you are still interested afterwards you will have a game in which you can sink hours and hours. So far I had no crashes or progression stopping bugs. Maybe a spelling error once but thats about all I experienced so far."

reviewText:
Thumbs up as a tabletop hex game.  Deep lore and game mechanics, immediately difficult.


I wish the developers created a more robust tutorial.  The game is pretty opaque and there is a ton of depth immediately upon starting, it could have benefited from a very simple learning campaign in which some of the complexity is reduced.  In two hours I have deduced that there are many onion layers of complexity under the hood and doing basic ♥♥♥♥ like outfitting your starting village for survival while you scout around is still fairly difficult.

I am at ends with investing in learning it (would probably take a few more hours in which I'm not having fun, more of making mistakes and restarting).  Part of the issue is that the UI is very click based, but not intuitive.  I spent about 3 hours watching videos and reading about mechanics, and two hours playing the game.  It hasn't reached the point of being more fun than another game, so I will come back to it later.

reviewText:
This is a really strange one to write a review for as it doesn't exactly fit into any of the established categories.  This is a good thing and a bad thing at the same time.  A good thing as original thinking and ideas are very thin on the ground in the video game industry these days, so kudos in gratuitous amounts to the developers for that.  A bad thing as the developers are breaking virgin ground and whenever that happens a few unexpected sinkholes are bound to open up beneath them.  If I were to sum up the game in a few words I would say that it's a 4X game that has a couple of X's missing, that tries hard to be open world while directing you along a somewhat linear quest path.  See how confusing this is?

Some clarification is in order.  4X stands for Explore, Expand, Exploit, Exterminate.  Thea has the Explore and the Exploit part but is completely AWOL when it comes to the Expand & Exterminate.  Expand is missing as you only have a single village to look after with no mechanic available to settle new ones.  Exterminate is missing as there are no Ai opponents, just generic fantasy critters wandering around in groups that get tougher to beat as the turn count rises.  There are lairs that spawn these groups ( at least I think they spawn at the lairs ), so taking these out gives a little respite.  Then there are ruins to explore and numerous random events and encounters to either screw you over or give a boost.  As far as the 4X goes though, that's it.  The main game is supposed to revolve around you being a weakened deity trying to direct your last few followers so that you can reclaim your powers and save the world from the darkness ( shades of the neverending story ), seriously, the devs couldn't come up with something better than THE DARKNESS?  Sounds okay I suppose and at the start the game is interesting and keeps you engaged.  After a few hours though the sheen wears off and it devolves into boring inventory management, equipment swapping, gathering, etc. while you attempt to put together an expedition hard enough to take on the next part of the main quest.  Combat comes down to a card mini-game that needs a major redesign as at the moment it is barely fit for purpose and quickly gets bloated with large groups.

The game as it stands feels like an unfinished, early access offering that still needs a few mechanics adding to it, but these developers are trying to break new ground while being very active, which is a brave thing to do in the current market.  The game receives regular updates and I am recommending it as new thinking in the industry deserves to be supported.  Thea has huge potential ( how many times have we heard that before ) and my hope is that these devs will polish that hidden gem.

reviewText:
This is a game that slipped under my radar, and probably many others. I can describe it best as a 4X/TBS with a bit of RPG Elements to it.

You can choose between a numer of leaders, of which has their own advantages, but you got to unlock those perks by playing the game, if you are really good you can win a game without unlucking all 5 levels.

You start of with a village and a few villagers, workers, gatherers, craftsmen and a number of different types of soldiers. You can craft, build and explore, research and gather.

There are randomly generated events, such as having to take cover for a curse, or having to deal with orcs that are semi hostile to you.

While only having one village causes some limitations, but opens up a great deal of thought behind your actions, do I leave my town undefended or not, do I send it out during daytime, or risk it during night where hostile mobs are more aggressive and the line of sight is very limited.

I enjoyed my 100+ hours with this game, and I cannot wait for future updates that will improve of all systems. Easy to play, hard to master, more depth then you might think, a great game.

reviewText:
When I first got this game, I wasn't expecting much. An RPG element game with a card based battle system. Done before, and most of them are mediocre at best, with bland card combat, so I wasn't expecting much, but it got good reviews, so I might as well try.

Am I glad I did... I cannot suggest this game enough.

Thea: The Awakening puts you into a darkened world,  where the underworld has leaked into the world. Consuming, and darkening everything it touches. You're task is to survive, and take your small band of people into an adventure to reverse this.

The game itself is beautifully balanced, with an awesome music track that sets the tone, and feel to the rest of the game and art style.

Managing your people and town

Unlike other 4x games, this one truly makes you feel like you're struggling to survive in a world that's quickly falling apart, and turning on you.

You start with a small village with only a few people, and a few warriors. The Gatherers gather the goods around the town, the crafters make whatever it is you sent them to do, and the warriors of course protect them. However, what sets this apart from most 4x games, is that again, it's set to feel like you're a small band of people struggling to survive.

Resources are scarce, your village influence range around your town does not expand, and you don't build new towns either. To properly gather the resources you need to build things, you will need to make adventurer parties with a few warriors, and gatherers, maybe a witch and healer, and find the resources you need, setup camp, and gather, then bring them back to your village.

Crafting and your people

In Thea: The Awakening each person is their own. You can give them equipment, see their individual stats, and what makes them them. As I mentioned before, resources are scarce, and rare, and therefore planning is needed for the future of your people. Who's going to be what, and where are they going to be going. A gatherer you plan to bring out in an expedition for resources will need better protection than a pitch fork and shirt.

Another wonderful addition to the game is the kids. Kids will randomly appear and be born, who will then grow into adults. Once they hit adult hood you can choose if they will be a warrior, crafter, or gatherer. On a random RNG roll you may also get a special option of something else, such as a witch, medic or one of the other specialties. These are rare however so you can't plan on them, but are always a welcome addition.

The fact the game simulates a true hardship of surviving in a dieing world being overtaken by darkness, the death of any of your members can be a real blow. Deaths are permenant, and you will need to bolster your ranks should you lose someone. They will take time to level up, grow, and become strong like the one you lost.

This to me is a very welcome addition as well over other 4x games where a loss is no big deal and I'll just make another one". In this game

reviewText:
An excellent game for players who enjoy storytelling, a bit of roleplay, and simple game mechanics that allow for a lot of complexity. Even after playing through it several times, you'll still find new ways to play through story events and combat, based on your current playthrough. The story events are all of a folklore or superstition theme, which can prove to be very rewarding if you're clever enough to understand them, or bewildering when that exact same cleverness gets you into trouble because you misinterpretted the event. Game instances can be long and methodical, or short and full of risk; regardless of whether you win or lose, you'll make progress toward future games thanks to every playthrough levelling your god, so feel free to experiment just to see what happens.

With that said, iteration isn't one of this game's strongest points. Games can run quite long, and the tech tree can be a real slog to progress through -- especially if you just want to experience all the story events, but keep finding yourself up against opponents that endanger your key villagers. There's also a lot of inventory management if you're the pack rat type that wants to collect ALL the resources. However, once you're far enough into your current game, these issues tend to lessen as your resource needs become more specific, and your villagers become increasingly capable.

All in all, Thea: The Awakening is quite a lot of fun.

reviewText:
I'm very much enjoying this game, despite some flaws. I don't think it's for everyone though.

Pros
+Highly customizable difficulty levels
+Challenging gameplay
+Good variety in types of gameplay
+High replay value (at least until completion, see below)
+Pretty good soundtrack

Pros/Cons
+/- Very punishing for small mistakes
+/- Auto-resolve feature almost always succeeds on lower level challenges (I personally love this)

Cons
-Repetitive gameplay in the challenges
-Poorly written dialogue / quests
-Initiative queue at times very arbitrary and frustrating
-Lack of endgame content

Post-completion rambling / final thoughts
The game has quite a few annoying and/or frustrating aspects but honestly the good outweighs the bad generally. The main problem I have, is that all motivation for replays sort of dies down after you've beaten the game once. I played on moderate difficulty settings (125%-165% usually) and needed quite a few attempts to actually beat the game. Not lastly because I usually restarted after losing an important villager. This didn't bother me, as I would immediately get back to it and try to beat the main quest with another group. Once I had actually done that however, there wasn't really anything interesting to do. I had a huge, fairly high level group, pretty good equipment and all the buildings so the only thing left to do was run around the map and clear hives / enemies, which frankly feels a bit pointless after a while. Of course you can then do another run with a different god but the gods don't really differ too much, apart from a few perks, so why bother?

Anyway, I had 60 hours of (mostly) fun with this game for ridiculously little money, as I bought in on sale. Would easily have been worth the 20€ they ask for normally.

Generally, don't buy it if:
-You're specifically looking for a great story or fantasy universe
-You have a low tolerance for frustration
-You don't like calculating damage values (pretty much the main thing you'll be doing in all challenges)

Otherwise, definitely recommended.

reviewText:
A really fantastic game. You can tell it was a labour of love, and that the developer's put a lot of thought into mechanics and gameplay.


Despite the amount of effort they've put in though, they slacked on one key detail: UI.

I've found that my major frustrations rarely, if ever, come from gameplay mistakes. It comes from navigating menu after menu to do simple tasks like analyze my party's equipment and stats. You have to constantly switch items between parties, click through each and every party member to see their equipment, there is no 'skip animation' setting for the combat, which can get drawn out and annoying after a while. 'Overview' menus for equipment and stats (a menu JUST for party stats would be great, actually), combining inventory and equipment.

The gist of it is: streamline menus. The combat can be dicey for some people, but I really enjoy it. The lore is really well done. Graphics are on par with a normal 4x game, audio could use a little more variety. Some bugs, but not overly rampant.

The core of this game is solid as diamond, just a little bit more polishing and this could easily be goty.

reviewText:
I'm very much enjoying this game, despite some flaws. I don't think it's for everyone though.

Pros
+Highly customizable difficulty levels
+Challenging gameplay
+Good variety in types of gameplay
+High replay value (at least until completion, see below)
+Pretty good soundtrack

Pros/Cons
+/- Very punishing for small mistakes
+/- Auto-resolve feature almost always succeeds on lower level challenges (I personally love this)

Cons
-Repetitive gameplay in the challenges
-Poorly written dialogue / quests
-Initiative queue at times very arbitrary and frustrating
-Lack of endgame content

Post-completion rambling / final thoughts
The game has quite a few annoying and/or frustrating aspects but honestly the good outweighs the bad generally. The main problem I have, is that all motivation for replays sort of dies down after you've beaten the game once. I played on moderate difficulty settings (125%-165% usually) and needed quite a few attempts to actually beat the game. Not lastly because I usually restarted after losing an important villager. This didn't bother me, as I would immediately get back to it and try to beat the main quest with another group. Once I had actually done that however, there wasn't really anything interesting to do. I had a huge, fairly high level group, pretty good equipment and all the buildings so the only thing left to do was run around the map and clear hives / enemies, which frankly feels a bit pointless after a while. Of course you can then do another run with a different god but the gods don't really differ too much, apart from a few perks, so why bother?

Anyway, I had 60 hours of (mostly) fun with this game for ridiculously little money, as I bought in on sale. Would easily have been worth the 20€ they ask for normally.

Generally, don't buy it if:
-You're specifically looking for a great story or fantasy universe
-You have a low tolerance for frustration
-You don't like calculating damage values (pretty much the main thing you'll be doing in all challenges)

Otherwise, definitely recommended.

reviewText:
An excellent game. There is seriously too much to talk about. So I'll try to briefly cover the main parts.

There are a lot of characters, each with unique portrates and all with varying degrees of skill. There are many different types of character: There are at least 5, if not 6 different races. Each race has multiple types of character. For example, humans might have Hunters, Bandits, Workers, Craftsmen, Warriors and Witches/Wise Men whereas goblins might have Boar Riders, Skirmishers, Shamen and so on. You can even recruit some beasts like the ones you commonly fight!

Equipment and Buildings! They work in a similar fasion to the Borderlands games, where each piece of equipment is made up of different parts that affect it's final stats. The only thing is that the system is far far simpiler, with only two component pieces per item, one primary and one secondary component. The order of the components changes the weapon too, so the main componant will give the weapon it's base stats and its' appearence while the second would usually impact the general quality of the item and occasionally add a boost to the second component's associated skill. The amount of combinations mean that you can find all sorts of varients for just one weapon.
The weapon stats themselves are very easy to understand but also complex enough for you to really get into designing your whole group. For example, your wise old man isn't going to be able to carry much, so while you might be able to make an absolute slab of a sword out of pure moon-stone that would wreck anyone, he probably can't lift the damn thing. So you probably want to find some dryad wood, the lightest building material for swords, and craft a less powerful but much lighter sword out of that.

Auto-resolve: Awwwww, yis.
I could just leave it like that but for the benefit of those paranoid of the auto-resolve option wiping their best team, I'll continue.

The auto-resolve option the game gives you is actually really fair. For the most part it will make the right call and your overpowered guys will trump the slightly less overpowered enemies. When you first start out and you've got no idea what stats affect what or how to play your cards to win, the auto-resolve function is your best friend. Once you get into the game and you get an idea of what you're doing you'll want to take the harder battles yourself, but you'll still use the auto-resolve function all the time for a number of things. I like to view it as a trust-worthy second in command. I'm crap at fighting large numbers of enemies. One or two dragons? Easy! Seventeen wolfs, rats, bees or a mixture of the above? I'm done. Party wiped and pride shattered. However, my trusty second in command is far better at dealing with poor quality, large quantity enemies than I am, so I let him take command for those fights. Usually works out pretty well!
It's also great for just skipping any low level enemies that insist on fighting you.

Story! I'll keep this bit short because you can't really go into detail without ruining it with spoilers, but the story is excellent. Both for the main campaign, the Giants campaign and for the general random events. The choice system is diverse and rewards you differently but appropriately for the apporaches you chose. You also get different options revealed to you depending on your party. For example, in one case you might be able to use brute strength to carve out some silver from a mine using just the rocks around it, or if you have tools with you then you can do a much easier challenge for the same, or a better, reward. Planning ahead is definitely rewarded and it's always good to keep your people well equipped.

That pretty much rounds up the main parts. There's still picking the different Gods to play as, the gathering system, the technology tree, the food and fuel system and many other parts.

Just get it. Get it and then figure out the rest as you play. It'll definitely be worth it!

reviewText:
Like others have said, this game beautifully merges 4X, rogue-like, and RPG genres into one very polished and entertaining title.  The fact that the scale of the game is small (one city with a handful of nameable villagers) makes you feel very connected to the game world.  I have been having a lot of fun with this one.  If you like games like Fallen Enchantress and Age of Wonders, you will love this.

PROS
+ Perfect blend of 4X, Rogue-like, and RPG
+ Highly customizable world set up (optional Save feature a major plus)
+ Tons of varied and interesting quests and events
+ Each villager's equipment and job can be assigned
+ Tons of weapons, armor, items and character skills
+ Multiple selectable dieties with upgradeable powers increases replayability
+ Decent tutorial system helps explain more complex features
+ Definitely has that just one more turn" appeal (very fun)

CONS
- One city with only a handful of upgrades may seem limiting at first
- Equipment/Item management can be time consuming (needs better way to compare items)
- Event/Battle card system is complex (but totally skippable)
- Interface can be difficult to read at times
- Isn't always clear what certain skills do
- Definitely has that "just one more turn" appeal (time sink)"

reviewText:
SUMMARY=========
a game where you manage a small group of people and resources to survive in a hostile environment. Explore the world to find better equipment, food, and resources, to fend off enemies coming to your doors. No two games are the same. Manage everything carefully, your items, your people, your materials, navigate your way wisely out of semirandom events while you try to discover what happened to the world. If you blink, your people may die.

CHECKLIST==========
Thea filled the big hole in my heart left by games I played in my youth like Colonization. Let's go through a checklist:
--You must manage over 20 different resources, CHECK.
--There's an immediate threat to your survival, you can't slack off, CHECK
--You can craft over a hundred different items, CHECK (and thousands if you factor in combinatorics, DOUBLE CHECK)
--The game punishes you for your mistakes and rewards you for what you did well, CHECK
--You can play iron man (no saving) by toggling a difficulty setting (that is, by design), CHECK
--There's music and it doesn't suck, it helps immersion, CHECK
--The art is good, it also helps with immersion. I specially praise the looks of the UI, the item icons, and the portraits, CHECK
--Asymmetrical AI: you don't fight equal opponents, you fight for survival in a hostile world, CHECK
--Deep, rich event system, with over a hundred different events that adapts to your party composition, their inventory, their deeds, all of it, CHECK
--There is more than one way to resolve conflict, you can avoid using violence, you can reason, you can use lateral thinking, the game allos you to play your way and tell yourself your own story. DOUBLE CHECK.
--Immense replayability given how many different things the game has that you won't see in your first playthrough, CHECK
--A research net with MEANINGFUL CHOICES that don't suck, DOUBLE CHECK
--The game has magic, but a subtle, difficult to access sort of magic, just like in King of Dragon Pass. It's not the overdone, everpresent magic of High Fantasy JRPGs. CHECK
--You can't just cast spells to heal" your wounds

reviewText:
Heres my take on this game...
I beat it after a few practice runs.

Overview:  Beat without the last tier crafting; and about 30~ residents. I ended up recruit 3 Elves, 1 Demon, 5 Hunters, 1 Sage, and 1 Witch. Not to mention my other standard guys. I was able to beat the entire main quest fairly easy, (mind you this was on normal).  MY main method was Social/Hunting/Attack. While there were other ways to overcome obstacles these became the most powerful as things like magic or hexing / sneaking become really hard to stack as you need specific character types.

While there were a few instances I felt confused such as the attack order which is used for every conflict resolution; sometimes its predictable who the enemy will attack so you can strategize; other times its just hectic.

The dialouge is ok; the story telling is nice; there are a few quests that are empty that will probably be filled later.

In the end; the crafting was very rewarding as was the gathering.
But the thing that I felt the game lacked was village options. Such as expanding my village to include more tiles; or being able to terra-form tiles; such as making a tile near your base wheat. Also; being able to found a new village or repair an abandoned village. Or traded with another village; as many of the tiles in the game can only be triggered once or for specific reasons like lifting a curse but it doesnt have the shops or traders that you can frequent that arent temporary.

In the end; this has potential and I honestly feel like this would be the template for an incredible FTP online game similar to Travian. But as it is a Solo-P at the moment the idea is brilliant and I cant help but feel like 15.99 was a complete steal.

RECOMMEND!

reviewText:
Awesome game that is quite the underdog here on Steam. I think this game should be much higher on the charts.

The game offers great replayability with its new map each time you play on top of you being able to set the difficulty of the game via several choices prior to launching a new game.
You have several gods to play, only a few at first but they unlock as you play more and more.
In the game you can craft items just like you want according to the resources you have at hand. There are no limits to the amount of people you can have in your community (had like 48 individuals in my last game at the end).
There are several ways to end the game, especially with the super hot update they have added lately. The giants are deadly, stay away from them unless you want to die or you have a party of at least 16 individuals with excellent gear and with an average level of 6 or higher.
The update also diversified the graphics, especially in the items department. This is superficial as graphics are not the drive of this game, it is the high replayability, but who would complain having a better looking game in the end?

Great game, to buy even at full price. Good lot of stuff in the game, and the designers seems to be interested in adding even more stuff... and if you try the game you'll realize that it has an almost infinite possibilities for expansions and big updates that adds things.

Oh! Did I mention that the game's universe is quite detailed and has good background. Most of it is read by a man, especially the important encounters and stories.

Three Thumbs up! I think this game will be as good as Heroes of Might & Magic III if they continue to develop it even though it is not quite the same genre (turn-based and random maps yes, but those are the only similarities.).

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Thea: The Awakening is the crossbreed of a rougelike, an RPG, and a survival manager with well-developed graphics and an intriugeing conflict resolution system. In essence, you play as a near-depowered god with barely a handful of followers left after the end of your world. You need to keep your followers alive, and lead them into the future.

Too bad about the monsters, though.
And the undead spirits...
And the plagues and sicknesses...
And the lack of food...

Well. you get the idea.
Pros:
-Card Game conflict means that there is an element of randomness in combat; what you draw determines your success.
-Engaging story and wide world keep interest.
-Wide variety of units and encounters make each game different.
-Random number god relatively forgiving at lower levels, preventing excessive ragequits.

Cons-
-Card game can become tedious, and auto-play feature can get valuble survivors killed.
-Still in playtesting; the game is not as user friendly as it could be.

I reccomend this game whole heartedly, but would encourage developers to make it more clear who is attacking whom during combat. This isn't always intutive when playing cards.

Otherwise, excellent game for those who want to play slower games.
