reviewText:
Early Access Review

Bravo. This game does something right and that is having a strong compelling theme and reinforcing it with interesting game mechanics. The result is a very immersive game.

You play as a God trying to regain their powers in a world steeped in darkness. You control one small city with only a handful of villagers each with different roles such as gatherers, warriors and workers. You need to form expedition parties to scavenge the lands for resources and equipment. You'll need to defend your city and go on quests to build your powers. Meanwhile you deal with events that help or hinder you on the way. If a villager dies it's lost forever and rarely do you get new villagers joining your city. This makes you invested in your little group of villagers.

The game mechanics aren't perfect - the resource gathering, construction and crafting needs a bit of work. I found the sheer amount of resources but the one-dimensional ways of utilize them to be a bit uninteresting. The combat can get a bit boring as well as you tend to encounter hordes of uninteresting enemies. These are things that can be improved though.

reviewText:
Thea: The Awakening is an unique mix of Strategy, Survival, Tactical Cardbased Combat (and Challenges), RPG and Roguelike.
It doesn't have the depth of each of those genres but the well balanced mix of all of them makes up for that.
The setting is a mix of fantasy and slavic mythology which is a nice change and especially the mythology part is nicely embedded in the many quests also the artstyle fits really well.

It's hard to list up and explain all the aspects of this game because everthing is well intertwined together. But everything adds one thing to the game either through randomness or depth: replayability.
There are a lot of ressources to discover, each one with unique abilitys. They are used in weapons, armor, tools and buildings which are getting different benefits depending on the material used to craft them. F.e.: A palisade out of gold attracts dwarfs to join your settlement, if it's made out of steel it attracts orcs instead; a weapon made out of blackwood gets a poison effect, if it's made out of obsidian it get's a bonus to stealth.
Since the game is randomly generated you usually get different ressources with an easy access each playthrough so you can focus on different things each time, like getting a good chance to get demons to join your village or make a lot of armor which boosts your magic. There are a lot of different races and skills to get out of this. But you also have to do risky expeditions later on to get to the usually rare and powerful ressources. And since the game has a day and night cycle it's not always a good idea to venture too far.
The many skills you can get are used mostly for challenges, but each has a purpose: either offensive, defensive or as a support skill. These challenges are using a tactical cardbased mechanic which is neither too simple nor too complex, it's well thought out.

The Randomness the game has is not for everyone, you can get absolutely screwed sometimes, and sometimes it can be a little too easy, but that's exactly why i like it: you just don't know what you'll get and even if you feel strong you can loose unexpectedly or at least suffer a heavy defeat.

The Game does have some downsides so far, but that's expected in early access.
The UI does it's job, but definitely could benefit from a lot of comfort features like shift-clicking to equip/unequip something, a filter function for the expedition creation and so on.
Spelling mistakes are relatively common, and after a while the fights against bees, crows etc. can get a little annoying. Also i think the endgame needs a little more balancing.
But that's nothing that can't be fixed before release.


Otherwise the game runs very stable, i didn't had any crashes or gamebreaking bugs and only one annoying bug i can remember after 50 hours.



If you can deal with the randomness you can easily get your value out of this game.

Edit after Release: They improved the UI and the hole game by a lot, the only thing i still don't like about this game is the tidious equipment management which can take a while, but other then that i don't have any complaint anymore.

reviewText:
I didn't know much about Thea.  I hadn't been following it and the little I had read about it left me cold.  With so many incredible fantasy 4X games out there (Endless Legend, Age of Wonders 3, Sorceror King, etc) why would I play Thea?  It's a £15 game from a small development house - what really is this going to bring to the table?

Then I read the review of the game on Explorminate and it was so glowing I thought I'd give it a quick look.  So I downloaded it.  That was over 80 turns and 4 hours ago!  I have not moved from my laptop since!

This game is absolutely fantastic.  The art style, the writing, the graphics, the exploration, the crafting, the quests, the customisation, the character of the world.  Everything is faultless.  It's even completely stable and runs like a dream.

I was initially put off by Thea's card based challenge system which is used to resolve combat, social interactions and tricky situations.  Put even this is fun and tactical.  It's like Gwent on steroids.

I really can't speak to highly of this game.  I get completely attached to my villagers as they join those already populating my settlement and become my best gatherers, warriors or craftsmen - only to meet their fate at the hands of a bear in a forest or undead skeleton in a dungeon.  Each loss is really felt.

I could go on about this game but if you really want to know about it then read the review on Explorminate and then buy it.  Stick with it for an hour or so and initial confusion will give way to pure pleasure and one of the most original and engrossing gaming experiences in recent memory.  I am searching for a criticism of the game and can't really find one.  It's early days but this is one I think I'm going to be playing for a long time to come.

reviewText:
Wow Thea has combined many of my favourite things in gaming:

- Mythology: Slavic mythology, it's very refreshing to have something different than for example Greek.
- Card game: So far 2 types of card battles.

* Battles that are about succes/failure in a decision you make. Like a mini cardbattle instead of rolling a dice for the outcome. These are not lethal (so far).
- Loot: Equipment, crafting mats, many stuffs!
- Research stuff, craft, gather, build, equip each your expedition crew instead of having just a unit that rolls out of the factory readymade. They have support skills as well that can be very usefull in some of these decision card battles.

There's so much in this game and this is only the beginning.

Watch the trailer, check the screenshots and read the reviews! Thea is amazing!
And buy it of course :)

reviewText:
A great little game, and a real gem of 2015.  This game offers a great storyline, whith some variation depending on your deity choice at the start.

The game is a resource management and questing turn based stretegy but conflict resolution is with a very intersting card based challenge system.  These cards are modified by character types, equipment and stats all which combine to give a huge variety of customisation of your characters.

The game is also quite brutal, many of your characters will die along the way.  This is the kind of game where demons sweep down at night and steal all your children and eat them, or your community is crippled by plague, disease, curse, or ... insert your favourite pestilance here...

With a randomly generated map every game is different, and resource placement on that map means wach game is a different challnge.

For fans of the genre there are hundreds of hours of gameplay here without being overly repeptetive.  The game could use more quests for sure, but there are plenty enough for a few replays.

4/5 - Loved it.

reviewText:
Pros:

• Great for Sid Meier's Civ players that want a break from the normal sid meier stuff
• Inventory system is good, can outfit several characters
• Stats like intellect, sneaking, hunting, trapping, etc - are valuable in many situations. Can bring up a lot of dialog

Inbetweeners:

• Limited to only one city, but with enough growth you can send out several expeditions or just one more to harvest the materials you need. I suppose this is reasonable due to the lore.. won't really find many settlements out there.
• Your characters die a lot -- if you're good at playing, this is probably not a problem at all and you may even like it. But when ♥♥♥♥ hits the fan you don't want your favorites to die, or maybe they just deserve it. Could use a casual mode.

Cons:
• Sound effects are buggy, music can reset randomly and some sound effects are missing / copy pasted.. like, a start combat click among other things.
• Graphics seem to be too pale for my liking, so I used that sweetFX mod.

All in all, pros outweigh the cons and since the game was recently released and the devs want to do more, I'd recommend this game.

reviewText:
Info:
====================
The hours played shown on my profile do not reflect how much I really played because you can play this game without Steam! In fact I played around 20 hours by now.


Rating:
====================
So far it is a beautiful and great game! It is complex and a fantastic mix of RPG and Survival. I love this game beside it's shortcomings I'll talk more about next. I refrain from repeating all the good that can be said about this game and has already been said hundredths of times here in the review section by others. If you want to know more about why exactly this game is so great please read theses reviews. If I could rate it by stars I would give it 4 stars out of 5. The fifth it would get if the following issues I have with the game would get fixed.


Constructive Feedback:
====================
1. UI Shortcomings
1.1. General UI Shortcomings
The UI is in dire need of some tweaking! The player has too much to click to get an overview and to do certain things. Another thing is the radial menu, it is often in the way of where I want to click leading to the click getting not recognized. Beside that I realized is that the UI is not consistent e.g. you can move your party via right click and drag but when you choose to move your party via the radial menu you have to left click on the target. One more thing that is irritating that you can't double click on things like towns and parties or whatever to open their dialogue windows like inventory and so on.
1.2. Quest Information
When hovering with the mouse over a quest marker on the map it should show a short quest description. Clicking on a quest marker on the map should open the quest window showing the latest information for that quest. Besides that the quest marker should indicate the difficulty of the quest like encounters are marked with skulls. Additionally the skull should be color coded for the different kind of fighting challenges so that the player can easily see that for example this one quest is a 3 skull social challenge and so on.
2. Repetitive Art Usage
Character portraits and character names get used repetitively leading to characters having the same name or character portrait. However, the user can at least change the name of the characters. Even better would be if a character name generator would be incorporated and if the user could use his own custom character portraits.

I reccomend this game, but not if you are looking for 30+ hours of gameplay out of it. It is absolutely excellent, a refreshingly new entry to the 4X (3X?) genre. It's not like anything you've ever played before, it's a genre hybrid between a large-party questing RPG, a card-battle game and a 4X strategy sim; very cool. Alas, each new game is the same quests (though you can make different choices). With a very simple tech tree and limited class choices, you will play nearly the same game on each playthrough. The story is really underrated. For example:

You meet a group of Orcs at an abandoned vault. Fearful of one another due to old legends from your ancestors that the other race were child eating brutes, you pass a social/speech check to team up by sharing half of the loot. It's an inspiring story and the female Orc leader offers you a drink.

By letting go of their differences and participating with each other they were able to easily overcome their obstacle but also their hatred for one another.

reviewText:
Okay. I DO enjoy this game. However, I recognise that not this game's market appeal is rather low.  Most people won't enjoy it because it is quite simply not accessible.

This game's main issue is that it has a stupidly large learning curve. It is that simple. There IS a tutorial available for the game, but the game is extremely poor at guiding you through the nuances of the mechanics and giving tips along the way on how to improve your play and keep villagers alive.  It really doesn't help that the game is on permament Iron Man  mode so you cannot take back moves and experiment with different approaches to the same problem.

Once you get over this learning curve however, the game suddenly becomes easy. Some folks say trivially easy.  Since I'm over that stupidly large learning curve, I'm now playing the game and I'm enjoying navigating my way through all the challenges and experimenting with different strategies.  So yes, in spite of the negative tone of this review, I actually recommend this game. It is a good game once you can get past the learning curve.

Recommendation: Before you start a battle or any type of challenge, learn how the card battle system works exactly. Do not try to learn it on the fly. The game does a very poor job of explaining, yet the card battle is a core gameplay activity that is used to resolve all encounters.

reviewText: I am an older gamer and for my taste I find Thea the awakening one of the most enjoyable games on Steam.   The artwork, story,  and music create a beautiful, engaging environment.   Thea has very unique game play.   I find that many RPG and 4x strategy games are overly complex and the process of learning the game not very enjoyable.   In Thea, you only have one villiage and one, or maybe two, adventure parties to manage unlike other 4X games where you may have 10 or more cities (planets, etc) to manange which soon becomes unwieldy.   This simplicity allows you to put more thought into the choices you are making in the game.     The technology tree is another example of where less is better.   The technology tree is relatively simple and intuitive compared to other 4x games that I have played.   But rather than making the game play simple, it makes your choices understandable and strategic.   FInally, I agree with those previous reviewers who like the card game system of combat.    It is refreshingly different from the Hex based squad combat that is ubiquitous.\n\nI highly recommend giving this game a try.

reviewText:
Refreshing to say the least.

I know my hours aren't the longest, but rest assured this game is a lot of fun. I'm deeply impressed with the mechanics and how the game works. It's engaging, has replayability, and is overall a breath of fresh air.

Tips:
I find my luck is much better with the gatherers. Not only do they bring in a hunting attribute, but they are also able to find vital rescources. Hunting saves me from a full frontal assault (and being maimed by a large rabbit).

Scouting is important, however staying close to the village in the start is more important. I can't tell you the number of times I've gone and veered off to a higher level to only be clobbered immensely. Quests, scouts, monsters, and other things will pop up so it's best to stay close to home.

If mortally wounded, ALWAYS camp immediately. Your chances of surviving increase dramatically.

Note that loosing one member will not stunt you, but loosing too many can land lock you. You won't be able to go through terrain, move, or camp. Your members will die of hunger unless you are able to send help from the village.

The game ultimately works against you. If it's not dark dwarves stealing your gold or an ice queen frozen at heart, it's a problematic situation which you can't get out of. Diplomacy is your friend to most of the random situations. Attacking wisps and travelers will only get you killed. Take the kindness and use it well.

Thanks for reading!

reviewText: Thea is a very good game. Its 4X fantasy game set in Slavic mythology. You play the role of a Slavic god guiding a few of the remaining humans in an attempt to restore your power. Researching opens the ability to farm resources which leads to the crafting of better items and weapons. Your town grows randomly, either by children growing into adults, visitors wanting to join your village, or sometimes, just because you rescued someone during an event. Not just humans either, you can get goblins, dwarves, even ghosts and demons! You expand by sending your people out on expeditions that can encounter events, complete quests, or simply gather resources for your next best weapon. My current game I have 5 expeditions now with a dozen peeps in each, all exploring and conquering different areas of the map. The exterminate part is a card game: its a brilliant, original idea. In fact, there are many different types of card games, not just combat, but also magic, hunting, sneaking, diplomacy to name some - and you can auto-resolve. There are many quests that you can follow, or choose to ignore if you want. The events add a role playing aspect to the game - and they are narrated. There is a nice event editor that MUHA provided graciously for free. The devs are very active in responding to emails and fixing bugs. One bug I reported, they fixed and I had the patch within an hour on a Saturday. They are also very willing to discuss enhancements to make their game better. I have spent 162 hours in game and counting. Its not getting old. And a really cool part is it doesnt matter if you win or loose your current game: when the game completes, it adds all the experience to a running total, which increases your ability as a Slavic god. I've played several games now and Veles (the god I have played in the previous game) is up to level 3 - as an example. There are several other gods to choose from, each with their own bonuses, and you can swap between them as much as you want. Its a really cool, inventive approach to a game. Very original. I'd love to see a similar space 4x game.

reviewText:
Great game! It surpassed all my expectations...Recommended for Civilization fans especially.

+ Slavic mythology. I was so bored already with Greek/Egyptian mythology in all the games. Finally something new!

+ Love the part where you are exploring the map finding different resources (it is like in Civilization)

+ Interesting combat system. All the combat/challenges are resolved through a card game.
+ Random events. Huge number of random events occurring = Endless re-playability
+ Gods. When you start the game you have to choose a God (it is like choosing a faction or race in other strategic games). The more you play the more abilities you unlock for your Gods (they become stronger).
+ Permadeath (this might not be positive for everyone). If one of your villagers get killed they stay dead.

I cant really think of any negative side in this game. Maybe I would just say, that if you like visuals in a game you might be disappointed because of the Card game element in the game. There are no animations... It is also quite time consuming like turn based games usually are.

Overall rating 9.5/10

Buy it now! ;-)

reviewText:
Played this game for a while, so now able to give a good review with a few critiques.

Overall this game is very fun, with many gods to play as (with different abilities, you have to get to level 3 w/ a God to unlock another random god).  Each god is pretty unique; one god focuses on night and stealth and attacking at night, while another might focus on gathering, so you followers may gather more local materials.

Game is roguelike, so you only get one save, so if you leave your base unprotected you might get attacked and all the villagers could be killed.  When the HP of your follower goes to 0 there is a chance next turn that he or she dies w/o fuel (wood types) or food (many types).

The crafting system is pretty deep.  Each time you do an event in the world you get exp that improves your followers (a lot of aspects, hp to carrying weight).  You can spend a research point in either crafting, resources, or buildings.  Crafting armor and bows is valuable, and can make difficult fights into normal ones.

There are day and night cycles so each turn seems more realistic than Civ 5 (where in 5000 BC you turn and you walked 1 mile in 1000 years, lol).  Certain gods have more advantages in day and night, and in most cases your visibility is hurt.

Enemy encounters are very dynamic, you don’t have to straight up fight them, you can use your intellect or social skills, so your whole party doesn’t have to be warriors.

Game has a great soundtrack, and even after playing a while doesn’t seem that repetitive.  Most of the main story seems to be voiced over at least at a B quality or higher (great price for the game).
Combat is a card game, so no unit manipulation, the largest party I was able to get before getting destroyed by 4-5 skull opponents was about 12.  The more cards you have the better.  Offensive and tactic cards make combat very versatile and unique, and challenging.  Since the game is challenging certain events and encounters really shift your expectations (let the demon do his magic in the town), or pushing cards to the front of the initiative line.

The stories and events are text based, which is fine.  The game could charge a higher premium of these encounters were voiced over completely.

Now for some of the negatives.  Somewhere around 10 hours of gameplay the encounters begin to feel repetitive.  Card art and some of the game art feels childish.  Feels like the developer hire an amateur artist to do most of the card art.  Battle cards are in black and white and seem sketched, not in full color.  There should be a way to total skip the tutorial altogether.

Often after you get tons of a equipment there is no quick way to ID the strength of an item (a level value) so you can speed the game up, or determine if you need to deconstruct the item or not.  There seems to be a lot of time soaking micromanagement when it comes to items and food.  Some of these things should be automated for the player.

An example in micromanagement when the expedition returns to town, they have to manage the inventory to make sure valuable fuel does not get burned.  Also itemizing every character is tedious.  I wish there was a button to take current inventory items and simply replace the followers current item in the party if the item level > current item level.

A major critique is the overall town.  Unlike civ it seems like you can only have 1 town.  The world is very huge, so I’m not sure how you meant to explore all of it b/c your party cannot venture that fare w/o food.  And there are no settlers, you can start a new town.  Even as a town crows the borders do not increase to encompass new materials to be gathered.   Seems like this part of the game is unfinished, and eventually it forces the player to be a warrior based party.

Card art should be fully colored and unique.

There should be more stories, almost as if they never repeat for the player.

Despite the critiques, and if they were addressed it would only ENHANCED an already good game.
The game is very unique, addicting, fun, and very well priced (especially during a sale).  The developer seems active over the first few days.  Stories are rich, the card game is challenging, soundtrack is solid, this game is defiantly 9/10, and could improve to a 10/10.

reviewText:
In an era of game creation where you either get a cookie cutter, or a marginally completed beta launch, the makers of Thea: The Awakening arrive on the scene to restore my faith in the video game industry.

I've played decades worth of strategy games, from old school blizzard and Lucas arts games, through the heroes of might and magic roller coaster ride (that is still disastrous) to the occasional glimpses of brilliance that was from giants like Total War, Red Alert, and Warcraft/Starcraft. I've seen good games. I've seen far more forgettable games, and I can count on one hand how many games caused me to sit down and lose track of time playing a strategy game. Thea made this list for me.

The approach for resource management is unique: you have a limited amount around your village, but you have to go out and earn the rest through conquest, dungeon delves, and the like. I found it quite engaging.
I found myself relishing the victories of my band of warriors, mourning the losses of the fallen, and being dumbfounded when my small band somehow took down a dragon, losing two and nearly 4 others in a random encounter where they fell through a pit in the floor.

I wish I had noticed the game back on Kickstarter, but I somehow missed it. I haven't been as pleased as I am now, however, supporting this tiny crew of game developers who put out an absolute jewel of a game.

I will be looking for more from these folks in the future...

reviewText:
In this game you really feel all the time and effort the devs put into the stories in quests and events. It is text-based so if you don't like to read it might not be for you, but if you do enjoy reading even a tiny bit this game makes you want to read. Rather than the same old 'go there, kill that, bring me this' quests you get lovely little stories and a lot of different options.

Wrestle the boars, just hide from the black smokestorm, invite the starving would-be robbers to join you for a meal instead, follow the suspicious cat and just end up watching it play with a ball of string, or just watch the nightmare catching demon do his thing and have a good night's sleep. The atmosphere is lovely (well, gloomy but very well done) and the art just suits it nicely.

Mechanically there are a few issues, like the time it takes to properly equip your people, but the devs are very active in the forums and still working on improving the game. Gotta give em props for that.

Long story short, if you like stories and atmosphere rather than bright colourful 3d animations and cutscenes this game might just be the one for you.

reviewText:
Live by the RNG, die by the RNG. Sometimes, you die by the RNG but don't know it for 20 turns, because you lost a powerful unit and newbie humans can't fight dragons.

*OR* you can use The One True Strategy and fight the same card game battle the same way 500 times, because the auto-resolve will eventually kill that really powerful unit and then you'll lose 20 turns later.

You'd think that with half a dozen different ways to win a battle you'd need to build a generalist party. Nope. Because that nerfs your ability to use the win method (combat) that can always be used, and then you lose that powerful unit, and then you lose 20 turns later. Because if you have a balanced party half the time your front line fighters will be half gatherers who can't carry heavy armor. That pesky RNG!!!

Just a tip - if you want to play this game, turn saves on in custom options and savescum. This is a really bad design for a Roguelike.

reviewText:
Now that Thea: The Awakening has been finally released from Early Access, I can say with confidence that this game is pretty great and worth every penny for prospective buyers.

I usually avoided Early Access titles due to the butthurt that I experienced with Godus and acquiring this game in Early Access without any foreknowledge of the gameplay was a bit of a gamble for me.

Question 1: So what the heck is this game all about?

This game is a turn based 4x fantasy post-apocalyptic survival game with a heavy influence of Slavic mythology as a source of its lore and adventures; my knowledge regarding to these myths is zero at all.

Question 2: Did it the setting and gameplay mixed well?

Absolutely, just think of Don't Strave, Civilization, and a trading card game welded seamlessly together.

The survival of yer motley village is a priority against hunger, cold and all manner of beast waiting to kill you at every turn but at the same time you must progress by finding better resources and making advance weapons for each member of the community to turn the tables of the fallout that happened before to your advantage.

The combat system or the card battles plays an important chunk of how you generally play in the world map. All characters have different stats and weapons that can be a matter of life or death depending on the resources you gather.

And to make your life a bit easier in Thea, you must choose a deity before the game start which can give ye a boost yer settlement and its inhabitants (Lada and Mokosh are both great for those wanting a good start).

Question 3: Neat! Anything not so great in this game?

Hmm for me the main quests is a bit short and the difficulty can really affect this one especially if you choose the map size into small. A high level group of 10-15 well equipped villagers can finish this singlehandedly.

Another comment for me, is the spamming of enemies is bit fast would make many new players camp (ha!) at the village and restricts them from exploring the world (this could be edited again at the difficulty option).

Question 4: Any additions you want to see in the future for this game?

If this game would have an expansion or dlc, I would like to see an expansion of the main/divine quest especially finishing these quests such as the rebuilding of the world, an AI/PVP between villages/rival deities and finally the terrain affecting the card battle.

Conclusion: Thea: The Awakening is a fresh take towards the 4x and Survival genres and those who love a good post apocalyptic setting with a unique battle system should try this.

Rating: Lada/10

reviewText:
While turn-based, survival, 4X strategy game with crafting and rogue-like elements sounds like they threw a bunch of buzzword dice into a blender, this game ends up being rather fun. It isn't that intense or complex, but it manages to be interesting, addictive, and challenging. It could be described as a brutal casual game; easy to lose, but also easy to pick up. More difficult in tactics than in strategy, and combat is unforgiving (though often avoidable).

Much of the novelty and challenge comes from the card-based combat and skill-check system. Each kind of skill check involves the same card game, but different skills contribute to the HP, Armour, Damage, and abilities of the character cards in different kinds of checks. You have to have a tactical mind or you will end up with half your team dead.

The illustrations and writing are good, but the voice acting gets a bit grating, and the in game graphics aren't great. It isn't just that the graphics look a bit dated, but also that the colour palette is so drearily brown-grey and lacking in contrast. However, this does make the event/npc illustrations really stand out as eery and magical. Strangely, despite the  quality of the event images, many of the character portraits are badly drawn. Maybe they are just bad at drawing hands?

reviewText:
Early Access Review

If you like Civ and Heroes, you will like this game.   It has elements of both with added elements all its own.

The card battle system is fun and flexible - each villager  is represented by a card that has multiple actions available depending on that villager's skills, weapons, and stats.

The scope of the game is much more intimate than either Civ or Heroes.   Every villager has a name and stats and equipment - from your gatherers and crafters to your warriors. Gatherers and Crafters can equip armor and weapons, and warriors can equip tools.

You get a single village and a limited number of villagers, but rather than making the game seem smaller, this makes the game more interesting and the stakes higher as any lost villager is a blow to the community.


The interface could use a little polishing but nothing game breaking and the game is still in early access.


If you're looking for a game that is fun and engaging without being overwhelming, Thea is a good choice.  Well worth the money.

reviewText:
I'm not sure why people are labeling this game as 4X. I'm not done with the game, but I've never eXpanded. The combat is interesting and rather fun but there is still too many things in combat that are indeterminate and as such are decided with a simple coin toss. This will sometimes be in your favor, and sometimes cause you a loss and wipe. Some very unintuitive thigns about the battle system.. if you try to sneak with a small party it is impossible, if you try to sneak with a huge party (20+) it is a cakewalk. The game has wired into the combat system that more villagers will make every aspect of the game easier (all aspects). So load everyone up in the minivan and drive on through Thea.

The UI could use some serious improvements in regards to equipment and resource management. It would be nice to see party wide stat aggregates. Expedition parties can become very large and knowing what your squad is capable of might take you 10 minutes of reading each of the villagers bio's. If the party aggregate stats could be listed up front, at least you would know what skills exist within the party. In regards to equipment, you will have to hover back and forth constantly to determine which gear will suit each villager best. There's no comparator.

However, this games (with it's flaws) is still fun. I do not know how to beat this game. On normal I always become surrounded by enemies that can one shot each one of my citizens. There will be 10 dragon nests within 8 tiles of my town and there's nothing I can do to clear it. On normal.. this seems odd, perhaps this game wasn't difficulty adjusted?

reviewText:
(Disclaimer: I tend to leave this game running in the background, so the hours played is more like 1/10th of what is shown here) - a testiment to the games stability.

Just Enough Rogue-like:
One of the features I like about this game, is the ability to customize your difficulty level by specifying various aspects of the game elements. Research speed, enemy progress speed, disabling saving, etc ... Changing these also impacts the rate of experience gain for unlocking and leveling your gods.

Thea: The Awakening gameplay consists mostly of crafting/research, exploration/combat, and quests (some random, some more story-based). You begin by selecting from several gods (some of which need to be unlocked by playing), which determines some bonuses for your villagers (such as research bonuses, combat bonuses, etc). Each of your villagers has their own typical RPG elements like levels, stats, equipment, etc...

Although there is a main quest line (which is basically the same) and diety quest lines, the game doesn't necessarily stop once those have been completed. You can choose continue on, or even stop before completing the quests lines. Gameplay is pretty simple and you can micromanage combat, or auto-resolve to speed things along.

The UI is simple enough to use, though could use some improvement in areas to make accessing some screens / information easier - but it is no reason to avoid this game.

Research is plentiful, and straight forward. There are lots of recipe combinations for crafting that consists of basically a primary and secondary material - keeps things interesting enough -- though I would enjoy more complexity or variance.

Overall I have not been able to play much of anything else, as I keep coming back to this one.

reviewText:
Thea: The Awakening is an indie 4X game developed by Muha Games. For the unfamiliar, 4X games stand for Explore, Expand, Exploit, and Exterminate, similar to the famous Civilization series.

Gameplay revolves around developing a single outpost by exploring the surrounding areas, collecting resources, and crafting items and equipment based upon what is available to you. The 3 primary character classes: Harvester, Warrior, and Craftsman make up the trinity of the explore, harvest, build cycle that fuels the expansion of your infrastructure and power.

Combat is card based (each character is a card), and the uses of each card depend on the characters abilities. There are many ways to engage an enemy in combat; if your exploring group is weak but has strong gathering abilities you can engage in a hunting challenge instead. These alternative fighting methods are preferable because characters can only die or suffer wounds in direct combat. Death is VERY punishing, on higher difficulties with Realism" (no duplicate buildings) it is difficult to acquire more characters
date: losing harvesters or craftsman can be a huge setback.\n\nAnd you will have setbacks. Thea introduces a system of random events that make each game a fresh experience. The random events are typically problems or encounters

reviewText:
This game is so complex but rich in flair, story, advice and tool tips. Where to start. I haven't played the first part of the campaign through, so bear with me.
(wall of text/)

You are a god! Cast out from the heavens or suchlike by the Darkness (evil stuff!). Fortunately you have believers and you set about finding your way back. (grossly shortened - I really like the story)

Characters: Each character (toon) can do two thing I guess: Fight and craft or gather. All toons can fight, but if it's a gathering toon he/she is strong in that respect. I started with 10 toons; 6 in a exploring party (think kinda D&D/roleplaying here) and 4 in the village - crafting and gathering. Each toon is very very different with different skills and abilities. You can merge the exploring party with the village and pick and choose which to go where. Food and wood and most critical to survive, and if your exploring party runs out of food you will starve and die.
When the party is exploring you will find some areas that has a icon above it. Event time! A screen comes up with your possible choices on it. You select one > Search ruin, and sometimes the ruin is abandoned and sometimes it's not. And this is leading to...

Fighting: This is where I was most sceptical because it's card driven, but I must admit I was wrong. I dislike card driven games but I really like it. Your fighters are the cards, some fight and some stay back supporting. The supporting toons use their skills to help a toon fighting. There's more to it than this. Oh, and keep some armour and weapons and the village. There's other partys running around with ill intent!

Crafting: This is where the game really shines. It's so simple and yet so complex. You can use nearly everything you gather or find. To make a hammer I used a iron bar, some wood and some other stuff (I can't remember). But if I used some other material, like steel, the time it took to make would be longer but the weight and the Research (see tech) would be greater. You can cook meals, develop tools, weapons, clothes and construct buildings. And when you click on a item, for instance a weapon, you can see what it's made out of! YAY!

Tech: You have a tech-tree and I noticed that when you search ruins and develop new tools you develop Research to do new things. There's Gathering, Crafting and Construction Research. I just researched and few Gathering things and when it's done I get 5 pieces at my village and a known location where I can get the stuff.

Village: It's fairly like Civilization and not like Civilization. There's children that grow up and you get another toon. But here is the smart thing: You decide if you need another fighter, gatherer or crafter. Sweet! You can do so much more. But the wall of text is growing too long.
(/wall of text)

In short: It's something like Civ/D&D/Warlords all put together. This game is so deep! But the game not fan of playing in full-screen mode. When I play it full-screen I have difficulty clicking on the buttons. There, I've said something bad about the game at last. ;)  Please look at the tutorials! You can't live without them!
It's something that the devs need to fix, but I'll play it nonetheless. It's too good to pass up!
...and yes. I played the game in window form not full-screen.

reviewText:
Thea is a curious mix of turn-based strategy and survival with a combat system based on a card game, and a story and setting based on Slavic mythology. The premise of the game is that darkness fell over the world, the gods went afk and only now a hundred years later is light returning. Along with light, the gods return (the player character being one of them) and you take control over a single village plus a small band of survivors. Your goal is to discover what happened to the world and restore your full power as a god.  In reality though, the goal is to gather enough food to survive and enough warriors to not be eaten by monsters.

The gameplay looks like Civilization at first as it's turn-based and the map is a hex grid, but the comparisons soon end. You lead your band of warriors around the map, searching for resources and treasure. Along the way you encounter quests, potential allies and enemies. Success or failure then depends on a card game, with the cards either based on your skills (hunting, social, poison etc) or your warriors prowess. The card game would take a while to explain so I recommend watching some gameplay, but it's fairly intuitive. It's good fun, rewards strategy and heavily punishes mistakes.

You also have a village to care of. Your villagers gather local resources, construct buildings and defend themselves from attack. Earning experience in the game grants you research points which can be used to unlock the means to construct new buildings, craft armour and weapons, as well as ever important recipes for food.  You'll require your warriors to bring back the rare materials needed to craft the good stuff of course.

The game is held together with a uniquely Slavic soundtrack and a choose your own adventure style story, entirely text based. Presented each game slightly differently thanks to an impressive amount of random events. I really like the game, even if part of me wishes it could evolve further towards Civilization in an expansion.

reviewText:
This game is so complex but rich in flair, story, advice and tool tips. Where to start. I haven't played the first part of the campaign through, so bear with me.
(wall of text/)

You are a god! Cast out from the heavens or suchlike by the Darkness (evil stuff!). Fortunately you have believers and you set about finding your way back. (grossly shortened - I really like the story)

Characters: Each character (toon) can do two thing I guess: Fight and craft or gather. All toons can fight, but if it's a gathering toon he/she is strong in that respect. I started with 10 toons; 6 in a exploring party (think kinda D&D/roleplaying here) and 4 in the village - crafting and gathering. Each toon is very very different with different skills and abilities. You can merge the exploring party with the village and pick and choose which to go where. Food and wood and most critical to survive, and if your exploring party runs out of food you will starve and die.
When the party is exploring you will find some areas that has a icon above it. Event time! A screen comes up with your possible choices on it. You select one > Search ruin, and sometimes the ruin is abandoned and sometimes it's not. And this is leading to...

Fighting: This is where I was most sceptical because it's card driven, but I must admit I was wrong. I dislike card driven games but I really like it. Your fighters are the cards, some fight and some stay back supporting. The supporting toons use their skills to help a toon fighting. There's more to it than this. Oh, and keep some armour and weapons and the village. There's other partys running around with ill intent!

Crafting: This is where the game really shines. It's so simple and yet so complex. You can use nearly everything you gather or find. To make a hammer I used a iron bar, some wood and some other stuff (I can't remember). But if I used some other material, like steel, the time it took to make would be longer but the weight and the Research (see tech) would be greater. You can cook meals, develop tools, weapons, clothes and construct buildings. And when you click on a item, for instance a weapon, you can see what it's made out of! YAY!

Tech: You have a tech-tree and I noticed that when you search ruins and develop new tools you develop Research to do new things. There's Gathering, Crafting and Construction Research. I just researched and few Gathering things and when it's done I get 5 pieces at my village and a known location where I can get the stuff.

Village: It's fairly like Civilization and not like Civilization. There's children that grow up and you get another toon. But here is the smart thing: You decide if you need another fighter, gatherer or crafter. Sweet! You can do so much more. But the wall of text is growing too long.
(/wall of text)

In short: It's something like Civ/D&D/Warlords all put together. This game is so deep! But the game not fan of playing in full-screen mode. When I play it full-screen I have difficulty clicking on the buttons. There, I've said something bad about the game at last. ;)  Please look at the tutorials! You can't live without them!
It's something that the devs need to fix, but I'll play it nonetheless. It's too good to pass up!
...and yes. I played the game in window form not full-screen.

reviewText:
Thea is a curious mix of turn-based strategy and survival with a combat system based on a card game, and a story and setting based on Slavic mythology. The premise of the game is that darkness fell over the world, the gods went afk and only now a hundred years later is light returning. Along with light, the gods return (the player character being one of them) and you take control over a single village plus a small band of survivors. Your goal is to discover what happened to the world and restore your full power as a god.  In reality though, the goal is to gather enough food to survive and enough warriors to not be eaten by monsters.

The gameplay looks like Civilization at first as it's turn-based and the map is a hex grid, but the comparisons soon end. You lead your band of warriors around the map, searching for resources and treasure. Along the way you encounter quests, potential allies and enemies. Success or failure then depends on a card game, with the cards either based on your skills (hunting, social, poison etc) or your warriors prowess. The card game would take a while to explain so I recommend watching some gameplay, but it's fairly intuitive. It's good fun, rewards strategy and heavily punishes mistakes.

You also have a village to care of. Your villagers gather local resources, construct buildings and defend themselves from attack. Earning experience in the game grants you research points which can be used to unlock the means to construct new buildings, craft armour and weapons, as well as ever important recipes for food.  You'll require your warriors to bring back the rare materials needed to craft the good stuff of course.

The game is held together with a uniquely Slavic soundtrack and a choose your own adventure style story, entirely text based. Presented each game slightly differently thanks to an impressive amount of random events. I really like the game, even if part of me wishes it could evolve further towards Civilization in an expansion.

reviewText:
Short Version

An atypical blend of turn-based strategy and survival RPG where resource management doesn't have to play a primary role, because the player's choice is king in Thea: The Awakening. Highly customizable difficulty settings and auto-resolvable battles allow you to choose a  level of challange that suits your personal preferences. The well-presented user interface also has helpful topics that drop down when you hover over any stat or icon.

Combat is fun, refreshing and simpler than you may think. Your characters (represented by cards) are randomly placed into the offensive or defensive positions on the board, you choose positions for your offensive cards on the battle area, use your defensive cards for buffs/debuffs and then each side will auto-battle by attacking opponents at either side of them.

Becoming familiar with the large number of icons and how to gather food and resources is a learning curve, but once surpassed reveals a highly rewarding combination of exploration, crafting and encounters with many curious characters, mysterious monsters and bizarre beings.

The main story arc is nicely voice-acted but in my opionin it's outdone by the excellent storytelling found in the numerous sidequests. Every encounter is accompanied by beautiful, painterly artwork (there really ought to be an artbook of some form available). The high-quality soundtrack is very easy on the ears, a nice fit for the fantasy theme.

For anyone on the fence about this due to the strategic/management/4x elements: just go fot it. Thea: The Awakening is the most rewarding, enjoyable RPG I have experienced on PC for a long while.

reviewText:
I wish there was a middle option for recommending... I bought this game based on the great reviews and while the game has many finely tuned options compared to most others, its really not all that. If i had to sum it up, id say i beat the game in 2 days witrh little problem. For a older gamer like myself thats a issue.

The crafting and skill point allocation system is nice.
Lots of different weapons, armor, and shield.
3 different classes - Dps, witch, and med.
A unique battle system. Unique in that you can eventually defeat your foes in different way - Fight, social, intelligence ect,

The game lacks longevity. While there are i think it was 7 different gods to play with, its the same play/story for each one.
While i do appreciate the deeply written story, the options provided really have no major significance. You will be given 2-4 differnt ways to answer a situation, but all lead towards the same path.

It is however a $20 game. Its not that its bad, its just not great. If you are completely bored and looking for a good story with some quick side fun, then Thea will do you right.

Sigh.. Where are all the new age RPG's with old Wizardry feel? Games seem to lack any real challenge and/or depth these days.

reviewText:
While this game looks promising, it really misses the mark. I genuinely like some things about this game, but there are too many rookie designer mistakes for me to recommend it. The encounter system is unbalanced. While the combat card mini-game is a novel idea that I warmed to initially, it somehow doesn't fully satisfy and is definitely repetitive after only a few bouts, lacking any deeper strategy or actual tough decisions. Also, I'm not sure how balanced the combat system is when an auto-resolved battle against some enemies resulted in zero wounds the first time, where another auto-resolved battle with the exact same enemy grouping resulted in one death and numerous wounded characters... Numerous small disappointments turns a promising purchase into a frustrating one.

City management is clunky and could be more intuitive. Character skills are poorly displayed and unclear in their application. Other systems within the game also feel incomplete. This game ends up being hard not because it's hard, but because the overall execution is either half-♥♥♥♥♥ or half-guessed (and thus only half-good). This game was so close to being really good, only to fall short - if maybe only slightly short, and in numerous ways.

Another gripe that doesn't necessarily impact gameplay, but is super annoying, is the dialogue scripting and choices. Almost every response you can choose from is written sarcasticly from an immature point of view. Example, when encountering a Goddess walking along in the forest, I had no options that demonstrated the humility due in such a situation, only banal 12-year old remarks such as Oh yea? So you're a goddess - so what of it?!" or some such dribble."

reviewText:
The premise of the game is actually quite good, typical Civilizations theme with its own style and the card game system is a  mostly fun mechanic. Unfortunately for those of you who are like me and can't stand unwinnable situations or any form of RNG then you won't find much enjoyment in this.

To be a bit more specific, this game is a resource management, exploration, economy progression system, that has a card game mechanic that influences all combat (And several non-combat) situations.

Your cards have an offensive stat value that determines the damage they will deal, when you play a card and end your turn your opponent gets a turn to play a card to the right of that card, barring certain skills. The leftmost card acts first in the combat phase and when each card attacks, they can only attack the nearest card to the left OR the right. Now at first this all seems fine and fairly easy to manipulate and keep enemies attacking who you want, but it doesn't just target the nearest, it chooses a random direction, THEN targets the nearest in that direction. In other words, you may have a formation set up for best efficiency and safety if your cards all attack in the proper directions, but they choose not to and instead use their 27 damage attack to kill the 1 health 3 damage spider instead of the 26 hp 32 damage spider queen, allowing the said queen to attack next turn, killing a card of yours which wounds your character.

Which brings me to the next subject, wounds. Wounds are fine, for the most part, until it becomes completely impossible to save a wounded character. They get a little hurt, get gravely wounded, you set up camp to keep them alive, a turn passes, they die. For seemingly no reason, my characters will die from wounds that should be healing whilst in camp and whilst having a medic. As far as I can tell there's no way to manually heal a wounded character. On a similar note, it's very much possible to run into enemies that are far beyond your power level who will just absolutely wipe the floor with you, and even if they don't SOMEONE will get wounded. Characters have to either be strong enough to win, or they will simply lose. Skill doesn't seem to have much to do with the combat and that disappoints me.

The next real negative thing would be the grind. Haven't played enough of it yet but there are several gods which each require a different god be levelled up to 3 to unlock, and you don't even get to choose who is unlocked.

TL;DR The game has the potential to be great, but with very little control over certain situations it's hard to like it. Cards randomly choosing which way to attack and completely ruining your plans, or randomly running into an enemy you have no chance against is just demoralizing.

Pending further investigation and a little more game time, this review/recommendation is subject to change. As it stands, with the knowledge I do have of it, I would not recommend it as I feel out of control.

reviewText:
A week ago I'd have said I loved this game. A complex, unusual, deeply themed strategy game with a surprisingly subtle card combat. Most importantly, a wide range of difficulties that actually mean something: a new player on Easy can probably win unspoiled. A modestly experienced player at 150% will be challenged. Anybody playing at 300% is going to have to sweat every single move.

But the developers listened to their hardcore players too much. The April update totally upended the difficulty curve. New player who hasn't figured out how to win by turn 200? Die. Skilled player playing casually who hasn't won by turn 200? Die. Player playing at the limits of your skill who can't win by turn 200? Die.

The hardcore player's fun is not every player's fun, and game developers who think so are deluded.

reviewText:
Sadly, very sadly I cannot recommend this.
I bought this because I thought it would be a nice blend between civilizations and RPG, and it is somewhat in that direction, true, but unfortunately there is SO. LITTLE. CONTENT.
I had great fun for the first 10 hours, enjoyed the next 5 hours, but after that I only wanted to win a game and see if there's more to it, but again sadly there isn't.

City:
You can build buildings (about 10 different ones) which all either boost a stat of people IN YOUR CITY (so it doesn't benefit your warriors roaming around the map) and/or give a chance for a new citizen to join you.
You can craft objects; different weapons, armours and crafting/gathering tools, also different kinds of food.
You can assign people to gather nearby resources ONLY in the 6 Hexes directly around your city, which may or may not have anything at all on them (random)
and... that's mostly it. There are sometimes random events like storms, demons which might be nice or naughty, or rites and festivals, in these you mostly have different options to choose from, which will give different results, but there are waaay to few of these to be interesting longer than a few hours.

Expedition:
Most of your gameplay will be your Expeditions. You form them in your City, you can send however many and whomever you want out. You need to give them food (else they take damage each turn) and fuel (else they cannot heal when they make camp), and preferably weapons and armor, as they will fight all the time. Out on the Map you encounter enemies which you can kill (or defeat through other means, like diplomacy or tactics) and different random events like a lone elven wanderer that may join you after you help them out, or a frosty queen and her escort which will send you on a quest.
You can make camp with your expedition, which allows your people to gather ressources from the 6 surrounding Hexes and heals them faster.
There IS a main-story, and quite some backstory if you are willing to read a lot of text, however I didn't find it intriguing enough to keep reading after the first 10 hours.

Bonus Hate:
Events sometimes let you trade items with travelers, but what you give them is ALWAYS RANDOM. So you might give your best weapon away for something useless, or you may offer someone fuel, and instead of giving them normal firewood you give them extremely rare ancient wood instead.

tl;dr:
TOO LITTLE CONTENT
if you're fine with 20 hours of fun, I DO recommend this!
If you want more, get something else.

Also I have to say that the combat is VERY well made, once you get behind it. It is less random than many people say, the trick is that you have to get the initiative and plan from there ;)

reviewText:
Early Access Review

This game has potential and the slavic setting is a breath of fresh air compared to the tired, overused fantasy tropes we see in a lot of games these days.  The artists on this game should be commended, they've done a great job on the artwork.

Unfortunately the gameplay here, and in particular the card battles become very stale, very quickly.  Whilst you are able to build up your group with decent equipment and skills to fight well, the system forces you to fight every minor battle as the auto-resolve option will always lead to members of your expeditions taking unnecessary wounds, which in turn will cause them to die.

At certain points in the game your opponents will suddenly spike in power.  The drive behind this system seems to assure that the players loses any of its developed group members.  This is not the steady curve of a fun challenge but a punishment and an excercise in player frustration.

Construction of a civ's buildings doesn't seem to do much.  I'm unaware if there is an unreported bug with this system but after constructing the buildings that were to help gain new people I didn't receive any new population for the entirety of my gaming session.

I certainly had high hopes for this game.  I love to support indie developers that have clever and fun gameplay, unfortunately I didn't find it here and sadly this will be the first game that I've sought a refund.

reviewText:
The best games drive you nuts. You get beat and you learn the game to get better. It wouldn't be nearly as awesome when things are going well  if it didn't suck so bad when things just don't go your way. This is true for every great game you've ever played. If you beat it no problem, it was totally forgettable no matter how cool the concept, graphics, atmosphere etc.
The key is, it has to keep you interested while things go bad and make you want to get better. There has to be something compelling to make you want to play more.
This game goes very badly a lot. You will have things that took a long time and careful planning to build taken away from you and you don't even get a proper fight. You get a lame card game.
I DO NOT understand the positive rating.
It's just lame.
It needs something fun in it.
Replace the card game mechanic with real fighting and it might be compelling.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Featuring hexagonal, turn-based strategic gameplay mixed with elements from several other genres, Thea starts out after a hundred years of darkness, throwing you into the mix as a god who is tasked with leading a small group of survivors. The goal is to keep those followers safe against the threats of the world, whilst helping them to prosper and ward off eternal darkness.

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=6iDtdAFqf6g

Inspired by Slavic Mythology and set in a game world that contains over 70 different types of creature, Thea looks to be an interesting prospect. MuHa claim that more than 200 non-linear dynamic events will be included, as well as over 4000 different items, crafting, a procedural world and multiple endings. Also, rewards and unlocks will carry over to your next playthrough, in order to encourage you to replay the game.

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=oI6d11QhDCY

My overall rating: 8/10.

reviewText: Early Access Review\n\nWhile this game was decent, I felt it had the potential to be so much more.  At first glance it reminded me of Civilization V as the map goes but you only have the one town.  Potential resources all around (that become visible when they are individually unlocked) but you find out really quick that while lesser resources can help earn research xp you mostly just focus on finding dragon bone and leather, mithril, ancient wood, moonstone and diamond (maybe some gold to build walls to attract dwarves) because those resources build the best items and all other ones are outclassed.  Oh and for structures; almost all of them are essentially useless.  The well feels like it should be nessasary but its uses are mundane, the herbalists hut and cabbage field are moot, the smith and totem might be useful... but by this time I tend to have enough villagers that can use magic that I don't need the totem and you'll only really need half a dozen good smiths to put out a steady churn of items.  The real structure to build is the pallisade because its the best at attracting townspeople.  This feels like a cool option but so many other races are useless, animals and demons (yes demons) are so weak (that's right, weak demons) that they are more of a hindrance, it's really all about attracting orcs or dwarves and by this I mean they are overpowered.  I could go on about other issues but I just realized I'd be here for an hour so I'll try and cut it short, there are just a lot of balancing issues.  Balancing issues and the game story is so short and predictable that replaying it to earn another god began to feel more tedious.  Now understand, this isn't a bad game.  This is still in Early access and I do think it has potential.  But a slight lack of content (could use a longer story line, more monsters and different encounters) and balance in game to make other resources or buildings more relevant makes the replay of this difficult for the 4 of us that have played this.  Keep your eye on this though, it's not quite done baking yet.

reviewText: Seeing a lot of positive reviews for Thea I decided to try it out.  The sad reality is, this game is pretty much Endless Legend without the beautiful art or depth.  The main selling points peopel will use for Thea are the Slavvic folklore and the card battle system.  While I have no particular opinion on the folklore, the card battle system is in my opinion, uninspired, repetitive and boring.  Characters seem to become wounded at random, I had characters who lost all their HP in combat receiving no wounds while characters who were hit only for 1/4 their HP received heavy wounds.\n\nBulding, research, expansion and actual conflict all feel lacking.  It's not a traditional 4X as you do not play against other civilizations, tribes or groups in your own situation, just AI controlled encounters.  It is a very slow game with many turns passing simply gathering the materials you need to build or craft.  I would recommend people try Endless Legend over Thea: The Awakening unless you have a particular penchant for Slavvic folklore.

reviewText:
Village pacing was fairly slow and unintuitive.  Aquisition of resources looks to be either based on lucky start position, or on sending out gathering expeditions.  I didn't get to a point where either of those seemed safe, interesting, realistic, or fun.  Research options don't look to advance the game in any meaningful way.

The card mini-game is incredibly high stakes.  Which is unfortunate; it looks like the meat and bones of the game.  Failing a combat challenge costs the expedition party.  I earned 2-3 villagers over an entire session, and lost 4-6 in a single failed combat round from a single bad expedition encounter.  This wasn't interesting, or challenging.

My best luck was skipping the encounters with the automation option.  However, the outcome of encounters I'd play through in the card mini-game was completely decoupled from the automation option.  I don't think the AI actually uses the mini-game at all.  Negative outcomes from success (wounds, etc) were much more marginal than my experiences playing the card game manually.  Even then, encounter difficulty" was hard to judge.  The skull system implies scaling challenges
date: but I didn't advance far enough to tell if that's absolute (HERE BE DRAGONS) or relative (THIS IS EASY FOR YOUR AMAZING PARTY).\n\nExploration and combat with my first expedition party was fun
recommended: when automating encounters.  I didn't feel like I got anything meaningful as a reward though.  More resources I couldn't use back at town yet?  Skimming research options doesn't show much meaningful short-term choices.  It was difficult to judge the awesomeness of long-term choices

reviewText:
If you like the idea of investing 5-10 hours into a game before the game engine starts having the enemy numbers increase drastically and outscale you massively with combats and events you cannot avoid, this is the game for you.

Masochists, this is your outlet.

Normal people, avoid at all costs.

It doesn't stop with the AI basically cheating to cover the lack of talent on the dev team, either.  There is one save state, and you aren't allowed to know when it is, either.  So if you hit load, you just magically load the save state from whenever it is - you can't see it before loading.  Just hitting the load button abandons your pogress and loads the save state from whenever the Hell.

Stupid.  That's just plain stupid.  It's anti-fun, anti-player, anti-norm stupidity.

The combat/challenge mechanic is extremely weak.  Basically, if you take a normal CCG and then dumb it down to the point that you have as much chance of winning if you played with your eyes closed, that's this mechanic.  The auto-resolve is hilariously awful.  Want to lose a combat where you are 3 levels higher than the opponents and want to do it fast?  AUTO-RESOLVE!  I genuinely do not think I have ever seen an auto-resolve so bad.  It's a mini-game within the game - will you lose a gatherer that the AI decided should be the main tank?  Will the AI cause a party wipe?  PLACE YOUR BETS!

When a dev basically admits that they have no idea how to balance a game and create a logical difficulty progression, then maybe they shouldn't develop games?  Go back to the thumbscrews and whips, guys, you're better when the torture is honest.

Okay look. I like this game. I enjoy it for the most part. I'm going to give some pros and cons here and elaborate a bit afterwards. This isn't going to take too long I hope.

Pros:
Relatively speedy gameplay despite being Turn Based.
Nice atmosphere and tone.
Extremely good voice acting.
Strong story with a good narrative approach.
Stylish yet simple.
Relatively complicated gameplay yet not too difficult to learn.
Artwork.
Fairly comprehensive.
Mostly interesting encounters.

Cons:
Stuttering.
RNG Insanity.
You are not given the proper choices you want for this game to be completely enjoyable(!).
Lack of opposing settlements and what seems to be an inability to expand your own settlement(?).
Lack of Multiplayer(?).
Very small text boxes.
The construction limit is too small.
Multiple Wells don't stack (Sorry, but that sucks).

Current Score - 7/10 - Decent.


Details:
1. The stuttering is caused by clicking on the show resource" button. It causes the game to begin stuttering like crazy.

2. Many of stat boxes have super small text which is very hard to read.

3. Here's the biggest issue I have with this game - you are not allowed to choose how your characters progress and which enchantments you place onto your items. This is abysmal. It relies massively on RNG

reviewText:
It's har to praise this game too much. For 1/4 the price of games like Civilization and the new HOMM games, you get a sort-of-hybrid between the two, that so far seem better than them. Yes I said it, better. This comes from a long-time fan of the Civ games, spending thousands of hours on 2 and 4 and hundreds on 5. Unfortunately they have not managed to renew the concept in a way to my liking over the years. While those games where revolutions in their own time, as HOMM 3, Thea seems like the new wine in 2015. However I am only 50 hours in, so I cannot say anything about the long-term playability yet. At least it's been a total blast so far.

This makes Thea so good:
- 1 village, perfect! Basebuilding always got tedious and repetitive in the late-game of other games anyway. It increases the feeling of beeing lonely and lost in a hostile world.
- Great resource system! You can build a ton of different weapons and other gear. Because the game emphasises several different challenges in addition to regular combat, you want to have specialists in a wide range of areas, like hunting, healing, magic etc. Because of this your characters, that will multiply in numbers after a while, will sport a wide range of differnent gear and abilities. Resources are scarce in the beginning and the game always provides newer and better resources that you can reach for, while providing use also for most of the low-tier ones.
- The combat system is easy to learn, but hard to master. The lever of potential for micro-management is very high, as in the rest of the game. Protip: When you have learned the system, turn up the animation speed (took me a while to realize this).
- A limited supply of people. This means that you need to take extra care of all of them, to make sure that they survive. You can give them names, etc. By the way, your camp can attract members of non-human species. Right now my civilization consists of 24 humans and a rock troll by the name of Brick.
- The icing on the cake is that the game seems virtually bugfree, no crashes, everything works as it should, like a clock. I've tried many indie-games where bugs take away from the experience, not with this one!

I'll get back to gaming, this game is recommended to all hobby-kings and nerd-rulers. *insert generic addiction warning here*

reviewText:
Thea is a unique turn-based strategy title, where it takes the idea of a 4X and mutates it to what I'd call a 3X, by removing expansion. Thea is not about gorwing your nation or tribe across multiple settlements but rather exploring and questing in order to expand your single settlement. As you play and fail (you will) you will gain XP which will increase the power of your god and unlock access to play as other dormant god's - who have different bonuses which encourage different styles of play.

I was hesitant at first due to the card game style of play, and it felt a little convoluted at first. But it starts to make a lot of sense as you play and you weigh in on the importance of different kinds of equipment.

The writing and lore is great and would recommend it to TBS and rogue-like fans alike.

reviewText:
The best survival game I've ever played, hands down.

There is a level of micromanagement and detail in this that is just beautiful. You craft and equip your villagers with tools and weapons and send them on explorations. You can freely combine materials and create a big variety of items. And since higher tier material is hard to come by, you have to consider who to give your equipment. There is a very good balance in this and lower tier materials never feel obsolete as crafting items is also a good way to gain research points for more materials and recipies.

On the other hand, the combat system is a simple but very tactical card game. And all of your statistics can matter as these challenges can be a variety of things. You can try and fight the orcs off and risk losing a few villagers, but you might just as well convince them to join forces with you! The amount of things each individual villager can do is amazing and it never feels forced to play a villager in a certain way (Your craftsman might be unusually strong and put up a good fight. Or maybe you have a smart Gatherer who can poison your enemies so you don't have to fight them)

I cannot recommend this game enough.

reviewText:
Great game, and worth the buy as is....but...


So much room for improvement too. Here's to hoping the developers read these reviews, because there is just so much potential here. This is review is basically going to be a wishlist of sorts of how I think this game could be made even better. It's already quite entertaining, so kudos on that front, but I just wish there was more to it.

First off, as has been noted by others, the city development tree is criminially limiting. One could easily play the game without ever building a single structure. I can understand why it's not about copying Civ and focusing on starting new settlements all over the map, but seriously, why can't I turn the one struggling hamlet into a thriving metropolis? This would be pretty easy to implement now that the game is a finished product. Have a set of graphic assets that represent the city in a tiered series of growth stages, each one taking up an additional hex on the map, where growing the city correspondingly expands influence for gathering. Have all manner of new buildings available, plus an upgrade option for improving existing structures once you have access to better resources. Churches, stone walls, schools, fish ponds, mage towers... so many possibilities.

Make these higher level structures resource sinks just the same as population is a resource sink. If the required resource is not available, the bonuses are not provided. Churches can provide divine protections by accepting resource offerings of prepared food from the people. Mage towers allow for the crafting of exclusive mage tower only magic gear and further boost the magic stat above the totem, but only if it is supplied with gems and precious metals. An advanced blacksmith that also provide unique craft recipies but needs coal to operate. Monster repellent towers that lower the incidence of negative events and attacks on the village in response to having such attacks increase as a built in game mechanic in response to a player's prosperity (e.g. tier 2 villages are attacked twice as often, tier 3 three times as often, and so on...) Conversely, a player could build a totem of battle that would actually draw more attacks to the village. A lot of possibilites that would only require minimal adjustments to the game.

Next, it wouldn't hurt at all to simply be more liberal with movement points. The primary reason the game is so glacially slow (which is it's greatest sin) is because it takes forever and a day to get from one place to another. Have a higher MP base value, and another unit stat that gets averaged out over the party that further augments MP (something that is also improved with gear, such as the speciality gear suggested above).

Last is the rarity of new units. Especially in the early portion of a game. I spend an inordinate amout of time savescumming in the first 200 rounds out of simple necessity. I know anyone I lose is basically irreplaceable. It's mildly annoying. Cabbage patch kids should be more frequent.

Hopefully the developers will take this into consideration, as it seems like this game is just inches away from being truly great. Now it's just really good but... eh....

reviewText:
Great game for the price. Really scratched the 4x itch I was looking for.

Pros:

Turn based card combat has a lot of significant decision making in it.
Lots of potential for replayability in unlockable gods.
Good spread of difficulty settings
Diverse range of random encounters and responses.

Cons:

The RNG in which direction your cards hit detracts from the strategy of the combat
Only one over-arching story line weakens the RPG appeal.
Crafting depth feels shallow. There are some clearly better and clearly worse options which makes the strategy of tech choices shallow.
Once you've seen a random encounter there are obviously better choices.

Overall: It's a strong 4X style game. The survival aspects of the game and the interesting combat + the replayability make it engaging. It's weaknesses do hurt the replayability somewhat but for it's price this game is worth it.

reviewText:
The mechanics of encounters - battles, discussions, hunts, sneaks, etc. - is pure brilliance. I don't know if they've reinvented the wheel here (so don't know whether to credit them for it or not), but it's superlogical, it's simple when it's supposed to be, and complex correspondingly. There are only very very few annoying random effects that would maybe make sense to have control over, but looking at the developers patching habits, there's a very high chance of any problems getting tweaked out.

UI is somewhat glumbsy at times, but of course adjustable to. Would like to see some improvement still.

Points for voice acting as well. There's a lot of text, with a clear professional, yet only one, voice actor reading through the dialogs, which makes the story so much easier to set into.

8/10 (so far)
